I understand your frustration. Toradol can provide quick relief, but it's often temporary. When it wears off, the migraine may return if the underlying cause isn't addressed. This highlights the importance of tackling the root causes of migraines, not just treating symptoms. Have you considered exploring metabolic approaches? Things like diet optimization and supporting energy metabolism can make a big difference long-term. I'd be happy to share some resources on these approaches if you're interested. Don't lose hope - there are always new strategies to try in managing migraine.

I have come across doctor's that don't pay attention. I used to be on prozac and my pcp gave me some migraine meds while in her office, despite me telling her it's not a normal migraine, it's a sinus migraine. I've had them since I was 8 years old. Well the migraine med mixed with the prozac and gave me a reaction. I felt paralyzed. I called the pharmacy because I couldn't remember what she gave me and she sent in a script. The pharmacist asks if I'm on prozac still and I said yes. He said those 2 meds can't be taken together. She knew I was on prozac because she upped my dosage at the same time she handed me the migraine meds. I never went back. This surgeon prescribed me some prilosec and the nurse tried to give me some. I now always ask what I'm taking and why. I said I can't have that because I'm on celexa and if they mix, I cannot stay awake. She said she would talk to the surgeon. She came back and said my pepcid ac meds would be ok to take. Didn't matter to me cuse I know what prilosec does to me, and I was not going to take it. I'm sorry you're going thru this. You mentioned that he said unless your concerns are in his charts, it doesn't matter. Are your concerns in there now? Because it does matter. What if your concern of an allergy isn't in there and "doesn't matter". He could hurt you or worse. If he's not concerned for your wellbeing, I don't think he's the surgeon for you.

She had THC in her system, I wonder how much. If it was trace amounts by the time she died, possibly Monday, how much was in her body when she ended up in the basement Saturday night? Enough to get the spins? Accident seems unlikely but I guess I could see it. She's got a crazy migraine, gets super high to manage it. The dog starts barking, maybe someone is in the backyard. Her head is just pounding, she's trying to hold it together on the phone. She drops the phone, staggers, trips over the dogs and goes head first into the piggy bank. Now she's bleeding profusely, hurt, confused, still tripping on the basement floor. The animals come to the top of the stairs to check on her but she screams at them to stay up there so they don't make a mess in the blood. I have a chocolate lab who will absolutely follow this for all of about an hour if there's been a spill or glass on the floor. But maybe she's semi conscious and repeating it frequently. The pants falling down, the random doors and palm prints, all that random unexplainable evidence could be explained but the fact that she was very high basically until blood loss cause it's own kind of delirium. Honestly, this reminds me a bit of the Rebecca Zahau case with the complete and total lack of evidence of outside party involvement. How can that even be possible

>Cylcobenraprene Presuming you meant Cyclobenzaprine, because that's what I am prescribed and have been on for years. This is not a headache / migraine treatment or preventative exactly. It is a muscle relaxant. That may not be suitable or relevant for a lot of people with migraine. In my case it sort of looks like: Injury > neurological damage > muscle spasms / knots (and insomnia) > migraines. In other words, for me, treating the muscle spasms(with meds and basically not working/laboring to incurr more muscle problems) reduces migraine frequency and severity. The side effect of drowsiness can be pretty severe, especially if I take at full prescription(3x daily, 10mg I think), but that's perfect, because I also have insomnia and getting tired a lot helps me get enough sleep. In cases where I still get a 10/10, I have "the big pill" Fioricet, I think (bottles always say "butalbital", which is also listed as an ingredient, so there's a weird circular thing when you try to look it up....but anyways) >Fioricet capsules contain a combination of acetaminophen, butalbital, and caffeine. Acetaminophen is a pain reliever and fever reducer. Butalbital is in a group of drugs called barbiturates. It relaxes muscle contractions involved in a tension headache. Caffeine is a central nervous system stimulant. It relaxes muscle contractions in blood vessels to improve blood flow. This usually cracks the bad ones, though it can take a few hours. Possibly because they basically have to be taken with food or they tear my stomach up really bad, I think it eats right through the lining when empty. I only ever take one, I took two once, as per "every 4 hours as needed"....never again, stomach pain for days. There are variations with aspirin instead of tylenol, and apparently even some with codeine. Never had those. A 4-way attack on the tension and migraine headache might be nice, but eh, when you ask too hard about this stuff you run the risk of looking like a drug seeker. At that, I have a scrip for like 15 of "the big pills" which, if I'm lucky, I fill once every 6 months because the rest keep me out of the range where there're necessary. Still chronic daily, but managing at 3 to 5 most of the time two 8's a week, instead of 4 to 8 and one or two 10's a week.

Okay, so they were texting constantly, all of a sudden the line disconnects during their call right after him hearing the dog whining and somehow he was not worried sick? My humble opinion is that it could be a stranger coming in through the backdoor, pushing her down the stairs (do we now if anything got stolen?) and roaming around for a little bit, leaving her downstairs waiting for them to be gone. I don't know what type of medication she was on for her migraine but maybe some of it could have had something blood thinning in it making it so her bleeding did not stop. In the end she had lost so much blood it was maybe too hard for her to physically move so she passed out and died in the basement? I am not that stuck on the dogs not going downstairs if the intruder(s) were inside for quite some time and her being passed out by the time they were gone - the dogs not being able to hear her anymore so there was no reason for them to go downstairs. I am honestly baffled by this case but also, if I were her husband and I had nothing to do with it, I would never forgive myself for not driving home the evening of the disconnected phone call. She would probably have still been alive at that point, accident or not.

‚ÄúSafe‚Äù when talking about triptans, to me, is a relative term. Is it safe? Clinically yes. Does is say you could literally die while taking it? Yes- but you haven‚Äôt, so you‚Äôre probably in the safe realm. Just remember, adding triptans means that if you take any OTC meds, you can only medicate 9 days a month with one or both or all of the medications, or risk contracting MOH, a secondary migraine disorder that makes your primary disorder more severe and chronic. Triptans + OTC meds gave me MOH which gave me 20-30 migraines a month. Now that I‚Äôve treated my MOH, I don‚Äôt touch Triptans and frankly don‚Äôt really consider otc meds ‚Äúsafe‚Äù either.

I also get postdrome and they feel different than acute VM. My postdromes have flu-like body aches, difficulty concentrating, lingering phonophobia, fatigue, and general malaise. When I have the migraine it feels like there‚Äôs a wall in my head blocking my ability to think/read/talk, vs postdrome my mind feels totally empty.

Have you tried high dose NSAID like naproxen 1000mg as a rescue med? Lamotrigine at 200mg to 300mg cut my aura and migraine phases right back to milder episodes of pins and needles/tingling/stinging, a slight drool/face droop and headach. Have not had a blind eye for over 6 years. It was the only drug that worked like this and has minimal side-effects. It also stopped the short absence seizure type activity that started and was finally the last straw to make me try it. In recent years, I added pregabalin for another condition and found that alongside lamotrigine I got even more resolution of the migraines and aura. Sometimes I took nortriptyline as well but started to worry too much about polypharmacy. If I stop lamotrigine (lamictal brand) my face droop and trigeminal nerve pain returns, then everything else. The aura became persistant after having status migranosus for more than 2 years. I still use naproxen for a classic migraine head pain if they occur.

Quick background: I'm 36M, had TBI when I was 8 years old. I can't go out without atlius tinted contact lenses, tinted glasses, clip-on sunglasses, and a hat, whether it's day or night. Botox seems to be the only thing that works for me, but after 3 years, it only works for about a month and a half. The other month and a half, I'm on average 2 or 3 out of 10, I can go a week without leaving the house, and I can't even go to my mailbox. I've tried numerous products that might help, and I'd say about 95% of them were failures. My wife told me about a product she saw on Instagram called ZOK Instant Migraine Relief. I hesitated to try it because most of these are posted to get a free product, and they sure don't post the negative ones. However, I decided to give it a try. I experienced great relief when I applied negative pressure to my left ear. It made me wonder if it could be related to vertigo, as neurologists never mentioned it. So, last week looked into the vertigo Epley maneuver., I went from being miserable 2/10 to 8/10 in just 4 minutes, and I had a fantastic day, which is not something I'm accustomed to. I kept doing it for the next few days, about 4-5 times a day, and half somersault maneuver, every time it gave me 1 hour or 2 of relief, which was great, but after that I went back to the dizziness; I kept doing the manoeuvers until yesterday I barely saw a difference, today too, the relief was still there but minimal. I'm not sure if I'm doing the right thing here. I got very excited for a few days, but now I'm back to feeling like nothing can help.

I have gotten migraines regularly for many years, but TMS is a noticeable trigger of them for me ‚Äì I think the coil is so close to the trigeminal nerve that it can trigger one by stimulating the nerve, and also by causing repetitive twitching of head/facial muscles which causes muscle tension which is another cause of migraines (at least for me). I‚Äôve noticed for myself that if the TMS session is more painful, it‚Äôs more likely to trigger a migraine - so like other people have said, it‚Äôs worth asking your technician to try a different angle of the coil. It‚Äôs also common that TMS is really painful for the first few sessions, but the pain diminishes with time, so maybe it will stop triggering migraines after the first week or two. If your migraines persist it‚Äôs also worth getting an abortive medication from your PCP - if you‚Äôre new to migraines they will probably start you off with a triptan (which is a class of migraine medication that you take when you have a migraine - it doesn‚Äôt prevent them). Also seconding an ice hat (I got a headache hat from Amazon and like it), as well as getting plenty of water and electrolytes, like Gatorade or chicken broth. Migraines are terrible and I hope for your sake that TMS remains the only trigger!

This was a fear of mine as well. I avoided trying any new products close to the wedding (make up/perfume/hairspray), I did not put my hair up (so no pins/hair tension to worry about), we had our wedding be a Sunday brunch rather than evening wedding (so no loud music or flashy lights, minimal alcohol, etc), I wore a supportive dress that did not require a weird bra or anything that would put too much stress on my shoulders, and I had my emergency kit with my abortive, excedrin migraine, electrolyte powder, ginger chews, salonpas patches, etc. I was very fortunate that I had a migraine-free (and chronic-pain free!) day. I also put a good amount of conscious effort into taking good care of myself for the week leading up to the wedding, and trying not to let myself spend too much time sitting and letting the anxiety build about whether Id have a migraine (or be able to walk properly, due to my other chronic issues lol). I drank lots of water, went to bed early, and was ready to take my abortives at the *slightest* sign a migraine was coming on. I was not going to play my usual (stupid) ‚Äúwait and see‚Äù game. Whether or not you get a migraine is in the (rather long) list of things that we just cannot control. Be prepared, but try not to ruminate on the negative what-ifs too much. The day will be how it will be. And at the end of the day you‚Äôll be married! Congratulations to you and your partner! I hope the planning doesn‚Äôt drive you too crazy, and I hope you have a beautiful pain-free wedding day ‚ù§Ô∏è

I‚Äôve read through your comments about the different meds and treatments you‚Äôve tried. I don‚Äôt say this to offend you, so please don‚Äôt take it that way. It sounds like you‚Äôre not being given enough time on any one med or combo to actually give them a chance to do anything. I know that can be infuriating to hear, it still pisses me off when my doctor says to ‚Äúgive it time‚Äù when I‚Äôm in the thick of an attack. But trust me, it‚Äôs true. For me, Botox has been a godsend. That said, treatment is typically done every 12 weeks and it becomes more and more effective each treatment. They say to allow for 3 treatments (so 9 months) for it to take full effect. I‚Äôm currently experiencing my first major attack (triggered by recent surgery) in about 7 months thanks to the Botox. I also get SPG blocks done at each treatment which are AMAZING and my doctor sends home the remaining solution as a nasal spray to use between office procedures. Triptans usually are advised against with this type of complex migraine, so it‚Äôs no surprise you‚Äôve not had much luck there. If you look up triptans w/ hemiplegic migraine there‚Äôs tons of reading material to go into detail. I‚Äôve gone thru several different meds and med combos over the last few years since my dx (took about 2 years of near constant aura to get a proper dx). Each med my neurologist had me try for at least 2-3 months before deciding unless I experienced severe side effects. We found that verapamil 360 mg works as a great starting off point for me. It worked on its own for about 6-8 months before it started to feel like it wasn‚Äôt quite enough. Instead of taking me off of the verapamil, we added topiramate which I loved - it was a great combo! Unfortunately, it contributes to kidney stones which I already am prone to so I had to stop taking it after about 9 months. I‚Äôve since started propranolol in addition to the verapamil which seems to be working well along with the Botox and spg block. For abortive meds, I take Benadryl and try to sleep at the first sign of aura. If that doesn‚Äôt do the trick after a few nights I‚Äôll start a high dose prednisone taper which usually does the trick. There are downsides to taking steroids frequently though, so my dr just ordered ubrelvy for me to try. I haven‚Äôt tried it yet as the approval process took forever, but it gets here tomorrow so we‚Äôll see. Sorry this was so long! Keep in mind what works for one might not work for you, but hopefully from all of the responses here you‚Äôll at least have some good talking points to take to your doctors. It sucks bigtime, but try to give each treatment time to do its thing.

I‚Äôm only going to comment on filling prescriptions and coverage of special treatments (with our health insurance company). You can choose any pharmacy you want and once you show them your health insurance card, you don‚Äôt typically pay anything on the spot. The pharmacy will bill your insurance company and you‚Äôll get a bill for your costs later. Also, ‚Äùfilling‚Äù prescriptions is not as painful as in the US. I had to visit a pharmacy in San Jose a couple of times and I couldn‚Äôt believe how inefficient it was. Here you show up with a prescription and more often than not you‚Äôre out of there with your meds in less than 5 minutes. No one is counting pills and putting them in a bottle. Almost everything is pre-packaged. Many doctors and health centers also have a little pharmacy on site and you can get your (basic) meds during your doc visit without having to go to a ‚Äùreal‚Äù pharmacy separately. That‚Äôs so much more convenient especially with sick kids. For more special treatments, the doctors typically know what‚Äôs always covered and if they need to make a case for the insurance. As an examply, one of my family members used a really expensive biological migraine medication for a while. That‚Äôs not covered until a certain regulated amount of other treatments has been tried. Once that was done, the neurologist did the application and the insurance sent us a written decision by mail. So we knew it will be covered and could order it to the local pharmacy. Afterwards we got the invoice for our share of the costs and which was negligible after two months.

I was 7 when diagnosed but looking back I was showing signs up to a year prior. My parents said that I was losing a lot of weight, drinking a lot of water, peeing a lot, low energy, not eating/snacking a lot. The week or so leading up to my diagnosis I had the swine flu (2009) so I was out of school, had the above symptoms, constant migraine, sleeping all day, as the week went on the got progressively weaker. By the time I was brought to the ER I was super pale and non-responsive (my family said I looked like I was dead), the doctor immediately smelt my breath (DKA has a fruity smell) and my sugar was in the high 900s and immediately sent for me to be transferred to a children‚Äôs hospital (more things happened after). But those were my symptoms all the way to a year prior to the day my parents took me to the ER

When I have a really bad headache or migraine I will usually do all of the following: - I will have some sort of caffeine while I take some meds for the pain or an abortive medication for migraines. - Take a hot shower in the dark - Apply Icyhot to my temples since they get painful and it is a good distraction from the pain. Also works for the back of the neck. - Use my Renpho eye massager. It seems to help quite a bit with eye pain especially since it has a heating element. I know some people won't put it over their eyes and have it just massage the forehead. - Use my IceBeanie that I keep in the fridge since the way it is designed it is too cold in the freezer for me. - I will usually try to eat spicy foods, and/or icecream to help distract and numb the pain. My go to food if I'm not totally knocked out from pain is a double cheeseburger, fries, large Dr. Pepper from McDonald's üòÇ - If all else fails I just try sleeping in the dark with meditation music. Eventually I fall asleep for a few hours and feel a bit better after. Hopefully some of these will be helpful to you!

i warn this is long because my health is WEIRD so this problem has a lot of necessary context. i have an arachnoid cyst that gave me severe chronic migraine as a child as it grew- however, it went dormant and i stopped having migraines when i was 11, so i never got it taken out (surgery was too risky when it could end up returning, since it wasnt causing issues anymore). at 22 i began having migraines again, 16-17 a month and had to leave my job because it was too debilitating. the doctor that did my new 2023 brain scans said that the cyst hadnt grown and so it wasnt causing them. i read the reports, i have a neuroscience degree and i dont think they expected me to understand them lol, but it DID grow about a cm, i guess just not enough for the doctor to worry‚Ä¶ either way, i went to a neurologist, was put on propranolol and suddenly went down to less than 1 migraine a month on average, it was amazing. about two or three months ago my insurance told me they would only cover one specific pharmacy and i had to transfer all my perscriptions from kroger pharmacy to the new one (carelon). the pills from this pharmacy look different, so i know they have a different provider for their generics‚Ä¶ and i also know that generics from different providers can have slightly different makeups. yay. i quickly noticed that both my metformin and my propranolol worked less efficiently with this new pharmacy, even when my metformin dose was raised. ive had more acne breakouts and have been exhausted all the time, two signs that my PCOS is not being controlled. i began having 4 or so migraines a month. i plan on discussing this with my neurologist in two weeks to see if she can get me put back to the old brand of generics. tldr: med brands switched by insurance a few months ago, dont work as well. i went to a concert last tuesday (as i write this it is 7 days after) and got a migraine, which i half expected because of how many flashing lights it had and the noise levels. no regrets, concert was amazing. the issue is that the day after, i got another migraine. two in a row these days is weird for me. had another concert thursday, third day with a migraine.. yesterday was the sixth day in a row. they always hit in the evening, like they did before i was medicated. i feel like my meds arent working at all all of a sudden. i can still work for now because they hit after work, but i wake up with postdrome and overall feel awful most of the time. at first, i thought my famotidine stopped working (for my GERD) because i lost my voice on thursday night until monday evening, which happens if i stop taking my famotidine. but i didnt stop. a cough developed over the weekend with mucus, so i guess it was a head cold i caught at the concert? my colestipol ALSO suddenly isnt working right, my diarrhea from post-cholesectomy syndrome has been uncontrollable this week. as of today, my famotidine is working again(?) but my colestipol and propranolol arent. i know that cold meds can mess with propranolol, but i only took one dose of dayquil on monday, and outside of that i had some cough drops across the weekend. but the daily migraines started before i began taking them- and if the concerts were the migraine cause, why am i still getting them a week later, with consistent predictable timing just like my unmedicated migraines? another note is that i have a new aura with these migraines: i get a mild acid/bile headache, like what i used to get before i had my gallbladder removed in 2021. these migraines have weird symptoms as well. my face gets very hot as if i have a fever, but i dont, and it feels normal to anyone who touches me. sometimes i turn red in the face. the rest of my usual symptoms are present- the light sensitivity is horrid, pain is not the worst migraine ive had but still debilitating, dizziness, nausea, blurry vision, sometimes confusion/disorientation. i was ANA tested a few years ago and it was negative, so as far as i know it isnt lupus, but i dont think i was tested during a ‚Äòflare‚Äô. lupus has been on my radar of possibility for a while now because i have blood family with it. and i work for a rheumatology clinic so i see lupus info a lot lol i know developed drug resistence is the likely answer, but the weird timing makes me think something else was involved im curious if anyone has any information I've been suffering from headaches for just under 2 years now. With no warning signs I simply woke up one day with a headache that refused to go away, didn't respond to any over the counter medication, and waxed and waned but never disappeared. Now it's been 2 years and I still haven't been able to go longer than 24 hours without a headache attack of some kind. I went to a doctor after 5 months of daily headaches, he ordered an MRI and labs that all came back normal and prescribed Fioricet. When the Fioricet didn't touch the pain, the medication journey began and I've since tried over the counters, vitamin supplements, sumatriptan, metoprolol, prednisone, Ajovy, Nurtec, diet changes, Daith piercings, magnesium, and more. Nothing has reduced my headache days or relieved any pain. I'm starting to worry nothing will ever work :/ My headaches have never behaved like typical migraines, which makes me worry they won't respond to migraine treatment. They're really more one long headache that waxes and wanes all day every day from low to mid level pain, not really your typical attack like people describe. No aura, pro drome, or post drome, and the pain isn't as intense as a lot of migraine sufferers describe, but it is constant. I do occasionally get light or sound sensitivity when the pain is worse however. Sorry for the bit of a long rambling post. I know 2 years and my number of treatments really isn't that long or that many in the migraine world üòÖ I guess i'm just looking for some reassurance from the more experienced migraine-ers that just because nothing has worked so far doesn't mean nothing ever will, because it's starting to feel that way. Especially because my new neurologist was incredibly confident the most recent combination would work, and still no effect. So many people praise the anti-CGRPs as miracle drugs, if Ajovy didn't work at all for me does that mean I'm out of luck with all the CGRP inhibitors? Or is there a chance another brand could still work? Regardless, thank you to anyone who read through this, it's nice to know there are other people who have gone through this same song and dance. And if not no worries! Here's the TLDR: should I start preparing for being just generally treatment resistant and accept I may not find a medication for me if 2 yrs of treatments have all failed with no impact on my headaches?

So, for my wedding, I planned a VERY casual day. We had a beach wedding only a couple hours from home. Friends and family came and stayed together at a big house. I scheduled my wedding for the late afternoon so there was NO rushing or stress. I HIGHLY recommend doing a low key, casual wedding. I wasn't stressed in the slightest. So, that helped. Some other things that I think made a difference: -I'm going to say this again: LOW stress. -I stuck to my regular sleep schedule as much as possible. -I made sure to eat all week before, stay hydrated, and keep gatorade around in case I needed something extra. -Pre-take Advil/Tylenol (if you aren't planning on drinking). I also took an abortive triptan just in case. -Is there a time of year where your migraines are worse due to weather? Perhaps don't schedule in those months. My neurologist told me all the current research says migraine brains HATE change. So, the best thing you can do is keep everything as routine as possible. My fingers are crossed for you. I made it through my day. Here's to yours and CONGRATS!

Badly... üòÖ In all honesty, I am currently working through this myself at the moment, and it's tough. The biggest hurdle for me was managing the stress migraine itself brings. Worrying about it ruining events, or it happening at bad times, or being upset when I do get a migraine. It's been a long process, and I'm not there yet, but I feel I am finally starting to accept migraine as part of my life and trying to take it in my stride. This is with a lot of meditation, self care and therapy. General stress for me is easier to manage. I have been getting help for my anxiety and suspected ADHD and realising that a lot of my stress can be managed in a healthier way. I think being undiagnosed with anxiety and likely ADHD for so long meant I couldn't address it or get help, but now I am accessing support I am noticing small improvements. It's really freeing to feel less stressed. One big takeaway for me is to rationalise everything. Why bother stressing about something you have no control over, or something that has happened? It's just a cycle of negativity, so now I reflect and move on and I feel free and much happier. Chronic pain is a loaded issue, and I can relate to feeling overwhelmed by it, I'm afraid I don't have any pointers here as I'm struggling with this still, but I do apply the same concepts above and don't let it take over as I know I have minimal control.

The following is how I helped my wife go from daily migraines to a few times a month... Red Lights If you have light sensitive migraines and have to be in a dark room, you may find using a red light allows you to see without causing light sensitive problems. Sleep and meal times. These are most often underrated factors in migraines. A good circadian rhythm is important for ALL areas of health. - Aim for 7 to 9 hours - Go to bed, wake up and have your main meals the same time each day (or at least within half hour of the same time). Even weekends Hydration Dehydration causes headaches and migraines Blood Sugar Buy a blood sugar monitor, they are very cheap. Diet and Supplements Suppliments - Magnesium: Start with 400-600mg/day. - Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): 400mg/day. - Keto or Carnivore Diet Avoid - Sugar: This includes white pasta, rice, bread. - MSG: Known migraine trigger. - Ultra processed food - Any food ingredient that looks like a scientific name or that you need to Google to see what it is. Stress Management - Mindfulness/Meditation:** Use apps like Waking Up or Headspace to manage stress. - A daily walk for at least half hour outside, preferably close to nature (park, field etc). Walking bar foot on grass for a few minutes really helps me. Medications - Triptans (Rizatriptan, Sumatriptan):** Use at migraine onset, no more than 3 times/week to avoid rebound headaches. - OTC Painkillers (Ibuprofen, Paracetamol):** Limit to avoid rebound headaches. Keep a Food, mood and symptom Diary A detailed diary will greatly help you to find migraine triggers. The best way is to use a spreadsheet I used the following columns: Date, Time, Food (list all ingredients), blood sugar level, Mood, Headache pain (1-10), Additional symptoms (aura, nausea, light sensitivity). Use an AI to Analyse the diary If possible use am AI like GPT or Gemini to analyse the diary. They are better at finding triggers we easily miss such as two foods combined causing migraines or triggers that cause migraines the following day. Upload the spreadsheet diary to the AI and ask the it to analyse the diary to find migraine triggers. Hooe this helps.

The main advantage of ER treatment is IVs. If you don't respond to toradol shots, a toradol IV can still work (some people don't have luck with the shots), and there are other meds they can add as well. So, if you want to avoid the ER but still escalate treatment, you could try to look for somewhere that does outpatient IVs. Some urgent cares do them, but many don't, so call first. Where I live the ER is the only option, but I have heard that in other places they have standalone infusion centers that can do this as well. If you have a GP or neurologist that is part of a larger hospital network or medical system, you could ask if they have something like this. If you can't find any good options for that, another possibility is to ask your doctor about getting a steroid taper. If you can get in contact with the doctor that normally manages your migraine prescriptions (either a GP/PCP or neuro can do it), they can often write a script for this without even having to see you in person. If you can't reach them quick enough, urgent care may also be able to provide this.

I'm so sorry this is happening to you. The four month taper is almost certainly the issue given how long you've been on the drug. Delayed onset withdrawal symptoms are not as uncommon as many think. Additional drugs can worsen your condition because it's very likely your nervous system is extra sensitive, so to speak, after stopping the SSRI. Reinstatement may help but there's no way to know ahead of time since it's been so long since your last dose. At this point the best practice is probably to reinstate a very low dose of the original medication (far below what would be considered therapeutic). I'm talking in the ballpark of like a single mg. Reinstating a tiny dose should make it fairly obvious if you feel just slightly better or slightly worse. If you feel slightly better or you feel the same, you can very slowly increase the dose until you see a change either positive or negative. You don't want to reinstate your previous dose all at once because your nervous system might be extra sensitive at this point. Reinstating a tiny dose protects you from making your condition much worse which might happen if you reinstate your original dose, while giving you a small signal about whether increasing the dose might help. Definitely look at survivingantidepressants.org. The experts on the forums there can help you better than anyone on Reddit can. Even most doctors tend not to be very well educated on deprescribing psychiatric drugs. The people on that website see cases like yours all the time. I would also double check your other medications for interactions before reinstating the SSRI, specifically migraine medications tend to interact with the serotonin system. Even if reinstatement doesn't help, it does seem to be the case that the vast, vast majority of people with protracted withdrawal type injuries do get better over time so there is hope! [Dr. Josef is helpful as well](https://youtu.be/clBCVXaTJCc?si=cSLfdl6WeR50nOr_)

I was 21(f) when I got my first one. My mother and older brother had them but I never really knew what it meant until I had my first one. I was driving when it hit, in the middle of a hot summer day. Thankfully I had a friend with me at the time because I had no idea what was happening, couldnt drive, and convinced I was dying. My friend took over driving and stopped at 711 to grab excedrine while trying to convince me it was a migraine. I was sitting on my passenger floorboard vomiting nonstop as he drove me home. The light was killing me, and I snapped at every word he spoke that was too loud. I spent the next 2 days in my dark, quiet room. Im 35 now. Ever since the first one, I routinely got migraines a few times a month. 2 years ago they changed and I needed a neurologist for the first time. Ive been told its not linked but im not convinced...2 years ago I tried birth control for the first time. 4 days after getting the Nexplanon implant, I got a migraine. It never went away. I went through the urgent cares, ER, PCP, and eventually a neuro. Ive been on Emgailty for over a year. 3 months after starting emgality, I had my first visual aura. So they changed again lol but emgality has helped a ton. Most days are just dull annoying pain in my head. A few bad migraines a few days a month. Ill take it.

Hmm. While reading this my mind kept going to autoimmune but I suppose that‚Äôs all been worked up. Has she had allergy testing or take any OTC antihistamines? It does sound like a possible underlying immune/histamine issue. Right, as others mentioned, I‚Äôd also question absorption and her diet. What does her iron panel look like? LFTs? Is she chronically dehydrated? Does she have any history of eating disorders? The constipation and chronic fatigue might be residual symptoms of previous maladaptive eating behaviors. Depakote can be helpful for migraine prophylaxis and is FDA-approved. Not sure if this would be a good fit for her but worth weighing as a possibility, some patients love it. Trauma, as someone else mentioned, may also be an avenue to explore. All of these combined to a degree, even. Good luck! Keep us posted on your approach and her response to treatment. I‚Äôm interested in hearing feedback. Also wonder what lifestyle changes she‚Äôs willing to make but, respectfully that‚Äôs hard to do without the mojo. Thus where we come in. A sleep study may be another route if she would be willing. Or even keeping a sleep diary for you to get a better picture of what her circadian rhythm and daily activity is looking like.

(not a doctor, just passing along info from a doctor that helped me) As I understand, migraines (the type I get at least) are more of a symptom than a cause. They can be caused by inflammation (of the inner head, I believe, but not sure). One cause of that can be anaphylaxis, which is where an antihistamine would help. I take benadryl at the onset and I believe it helps stop the cause of the migraine. Anyone who gets migraines should be taking a triptan if they can. Ask a doctor. Generally they are small pills with minimal side effects. If they are bad enough to require botox, you should also probably be taking a cgrp inhibitor once a month as a preventative. And, possibly, a painkiller at onset. Less pain = less inflammation = less chance at rebound migraine. I believe you can take a triptan + antihistamine + painkiller + nsaid at once at onset (ask a doctor about conflicts with other meds though).

#migraine #migrainerelief What is a migraine? It is much more than just a #headache ; it is a neurological condition with attacks that can last for days. While headache pain is the most recognized symptom, migraine attacks involve a wide range of other symptoms. These can include neurological symptoms known as aura, which may present as visual disturbances (like flashing or zigzagging lights, often described as a kaleidoscope appearance), numbness, weakness, double vision, vertigo, difficulty speaking, and more. These symptoms generally occur before the headache begins. There are also premonitory symptoms that may appear before the headache, such as fatigue, yawning, increased thirst or hunger. After the attack, symptoms like tiredness and difficulty concentrating can persist. Migraine attacks are often more complex than many realize. If you think you suffer from migraine attacks, be sure to discuss your symptoms with your healthcare provider and follow this channel for more tips and treatments. #pain #headaches #medicine #neurology #migraines

The only preventative treatment that I've responded to has been Vyepti 300mg IV infusion. Each round is 3 months apart. The effects are supposed to be accumulative. I've only done 3 rounds so far, but there was a noticeable difference after this 3rd round. It has me down to 25 days a month. My general cognitive clarity is the biggest difference. I am also technically taking Botox as preventative, but it's mainly just listed that way for the insurance. It actually doesn't work for me as a preventative, but it does help as an acute treatment for some of the muscular problems surrounding my eye. I take riboflavin 400mg daily, & magnesium glycinate 400mg daily as recommended by my neuro. I personally didn't have low levels when i started them. They haven't made me feel different, but they aren't hurting anything, so I stick with them jic. Trudhesa 0.725mg/spray & Ubrelvy have been the only acute medications that I've had a response to taking. Both medications say to take the 1st dose then another 2 hours later if needed. With both meds, I always have to take a 2nd dose. I'm hoping that as the migraines generally improve, I'll be able to get down to 1 dose. Trudhesa will make the migraine completely stop 80% of the time. Then I'll have 24-36 hrs free before the next one starts. Ubrelvy makes it stop 60% of the time. It's around 24 hrs before the next one.

The biggest strain migraines have put on my husband and I's relationship is just him hating how reactive I've been about managing it instead of being proactive. And he's not wrong, me waiting until I was 25+ to see a doctor about migraines has probably done more harm than good, but the migraines themselves have never been an issue for him. I think it's super important to communicate needs and set expectations for yourself and your SO. For example, if I tell my husband "I'm getting a migraine, I need to take some medicine and lay down" we both know it means I need to be left alone for a few hours until I'm ready to function again. I'm not asking him to do anything for me, I'm just asking him to wait for me because that's really all I need from him. But if you need more support than that, let them know so there's no resentment building on either side because unspoken expectations are being unmet/exceeded.

Experiencing pain in the left side of your head and shoulder can be concerning and uncomfortable. This type of pain can arise from various causes, ranging from muscle tension to more serious medical conditions. In this blog, we‚Äôll delve into the possible causes, symptoms, and remedies for left head and shoulder pain. # Common Causes of Left Head and Shoulder Pain 1. **Tension Headaches:** * Tension headaches are among the most common causes of head pain. They are often triggered by stress, poor posture, or muscle strain. The pain typically feels like a tight band around the head and can radiate to the shoulders. 2. **Cervical Radiculopathy:** * This condition occurs when a nerve in the neck becomes compressed or irritated. It can lead to pain that radiates from the neck to the shoulder and down the arm, often accompanied by numbness or tingling. 3. **Shoulder Injuries:** * Injuries to the shoulder, such as rotator cuff tears or bursitis, can cause pain that may also be felt in the head. Overuse or trauma can lead to inflammation and discomfort. 4. **Migraine:** * Migraines often cause unilateral head pain, typically on one side. Symptoms can include nausea, sensitivity to light, and visual disturbances. While migraines usually don‚Äôt directly cause shoulder pain, tension from headache discomfort can lead to shoulder tightness. 5. **Heart Conditions:** * Although less common, pain in the left shoulder and head can sometimes be a sign of heart-related issues, especially if accompanied by other symptoms like shortness of breath, chest pain, or radiating pain in the arm. 6. **Anxiety and Stress:** * Emotional stress and anxiety can lead to muscle tension, which may result in pain in the head and shoulders. It is essential to address the underlying anxiety to alleviate the physical symptoms. # Symptoms to Watch For When experiencing left head and shoulder pain, it‚Äôs important to be aware of accompanying symptoms, which may include: * Numbness or tingling in the arm or hand * Dizziness or lightheadedness * Weakness in the shoulder or arm * Swelling or bruising around the shoulder * Changes in vision or speech If you experience severe pain or any alarming symptoms, seek medical attention promptly. # Home Remedies and Treatment Options Here are some effective ways to manage left head and shoulder pain: 1. **Rest and Relaxation:** * Taking a break and resting can help alleviate tension. Consider practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or meditation. 2. **Heat or Cold Therapy:** * Applying a warm compress or heating pad to the shoulder can help relax tight muscles. Alternatively, cold packs can reduce inflammation and numb the pain. 3. **Over-the-Counter Pain Relievers:** * Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen, can help relieve pain and reduce inflammation. 4. **Gentle Stretching and Exercises:** * Incorporating gentle neck and shoulder stretches can improve flexibility and relieve tension. However, avoid any movements that exacerbate the pain. 5. **Physical Therapy:** * If pain persists, consulting a physical therapist can provide targeted exercises and techniques to strengthen the shoulder and neck muscles. 6. **Consult a Healthcare Professional:** * If the pain is severe, persistent, or accompanied by other concerning symptoms, it‚Äôs essential to seek medical advice for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. # Conclusion Left head and shoulder pain can stem from a variety of causes, some of which are relatively benign, while others may require medical attention. By understanding the potential causes and taking proactive measures, you can effectively manage your symptoms and improve your quality of life. If you have any concerns about your pain, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out to a healthcare professional for personalized guidance. do not feel bad about it at all! do what's best for you. the reason I asked about sinus headache is that that often is a question neurologists and headache specialists will ask because 90% of self-reported sinus headaches are migraine. And because many people don't realize that their sinus headache is migraine, it can progress & develop into another migraine type at a different point in life. (it happened to me, it happens to many) I hope rizatriptan gives you relief. if it doesn't, don't be upset. triptans typically are not very effective later on during a migraine attack and you may need to request a steroid taper. Another effective medication for vestibular migraine that you can discuss with your doctor (but they may not feel comfortable prescribing, which is why I sent the Dr Teixido video) is a benzo - that's the most effective acute medication for dizziness (esp when in a dire situation) but it cannot be taken frequently. I hope this information is helpful. there is a vestibular migraine reddit group where you can find tips as well and you may be able to get more info there! peppermint oil is popular among those with VM. I hope you return to baseline soon!

Yes, I have. Mine started when I was 15. That was a long time ago so there wasn't a lot of support or information and I didn't track them. I've had them my whole life and I got them around 4-10 times a month. I also don't track my triggers (I have reasons for that). I started tracking when I got them (but that's all; no triggers or any other information) in 2019 and then in 2021 I went 4.5 months without one and then a month with 4 migraines and then went 3 months without one and then one migraine the next month and then a month and a half gap and then months of normal again and then 6 months without one and then it was regular amount of migraines and then one month gap and variations of that and I'm back on my second month without an attack. I have never in my life before gone a month without a migraine before 2021. I changed nothing. No new medications; no lifestyle changes; no change in diet. The only change was I got older (obviously). The only medication I take for migraines is Maxalt and 1/2 a Tylenol #3 when I get them. Migraines are a complex neurological disease. There is so much that is unknown about it and people like the known. I am not convinced that it is things that we do or don't do that brings on an attack. Triggers are SO hard to pinpoint and it could be a multitude of things we did or didn't do or experienced that week, day, hour or minute. I feel that this is hold over from before when there wasn't anything to treat them and doctors were convinced that it was what we did that made them happen.

Do you suffer from #headaches #migraine #pain Migraine affects over 50 million people in the U.S! Yet, many individuals do not seek or receive proper care. The reasons for this vary, from lack of awareness about available treatments to the misperception that migraine attacks are simply just headaches that one must endure. This underlines the importance of increasing awareness and education about migraine, encouraging those affected to seek the help they need. Fortunately, there are several effective ways to manage these disabling headaches. Lifestyle changes such as sleep habits, diet, and exercise can play a crucial role in reducing the frequency and severity of migraine attacks. There are various medications available, ranging from over-the-counter pain relievers, to prescription drugs and even injections. You don‚Äôt have to endure migraine attacks alone. By seeking appropriate care and making informed lifestyle choices, you can significantly reduce the impact of migraines on your daily life. If you think you suffer from migraine attacks, be sure to discuss with your healthcare provider and follow this channel for more headache tips and treatments, and take the first step toward a migraine-free life.

Seconding fioricet. It's the only med I have tried over the years that has helped. like the above, I take it with 1 benadryl and sometimes a cup of coffee at the first sign of my aura. It basically stops me from barreling into a full-blown migraine. I still will have a mid-grade headache, light/smell sensitivity, and brain fog, but I am still functional and don't need to be in bed. If I have to, I can continue to function almost normally, but I am more tired and foggy than usual. I only get true migraines every couple months now, and this has worked remarkably well for me for almost 10 years. My neuro likely wouldn't keep prescribing it if I had more frequent migraines since it has a risk of addiction, but I rarely take more than 2 in a month so she keeps prescribing (for now). Every other med, aside from botox (which has greatly helped my daily headaches but hasn't seemed to change my aura migraines), either didn't work, gave me terrible side effects, or both. I see you have a young child - I would suggest considering hormones as being part of the picture. I know certain birth controls really ramped up my migraines, as well as times of my life where my hormones were out of whack. Could be worth exploring!

So glad you mentioned therapy. a CBT therapist helped me rework my beliefs and thoughts so they were believable AND helpful. I also ended up with a toolbox full of daily extended release breathing exercises (engages the parasympathetic nervous system), weekly mindfulness, and boundary setting skills. I‚Äôm back in therapy even though my life is fine because it‚Äôs good to process my life with someone supportive. I stopped eating trigger foods, too and (per my app) my migraine days are consistently down - I still get them occasionally but I think those are organic migraines my body produces vs tension type headaches that induce a migraine.

If you can afford it, therapy could be a good option to get to the root of your stress. I‚Äôm AuDHD and I have other chronic health issues, so always having some sort of plan/schedule whether it‚Äôs daily living or if I have a migraine on a family trip lifts a weight off my shoulders. Meds and THC were helpful for me but they can only go so far, especially if you are neurodivergent or have certain chemical imbalances. Stress management as a chronically ill person feels impossible, but you‚Äôre already on the right track by asking for help. Stress is a natural biological response, but we have the same reaction chemically to public speaking as we would if we were being chased by a lion. Your body is just trying to stay alive. Lean in to your support system, if you don‚Äôt have one, make one. Get into hobbies, for me it was exercise and yoga. Find safe people/methods to express yourself.

April 5, 2008. It's 3pm. I just woke up after attending an all night charity fundraiser at college. I got back to the dorm around 8am. I'd had headaches before, but this was the first migraine. Woke up and held was pounding, the light streaming in through the window was aggravating and my dormmates making noise up and down the halls made me want to die. I went to the bathroom and nearly puked from the lights and smells. Went back to bed and passed out after taking some advil. My mom called later on to ask how the fundraiser did, and I told her I had a migraine and couldn't talk. She asked how I knew it was a migraine. My exact words: because the sound of your voice makes me want to kill myself. She quickly hung up. I started having them frequently. Like... very very frequently. 4-5x a week. I ended up dropping out due to my inability to go to class because excedrin had stopped working less than a year in. Don't wait like I did. See a doctor immediately. I would probably be in a much different place in life if I'd started seeing a doctor in 2008, instead of 2012.
Abby can tell I have a migraine, she knocked the pill bottle at me.

I'll admit, managing abdominal migraines is hella challenging, but I'll provide whatever input that I can and have personally found helpful, and you can take it or leave it üòä Medications like triptans can be effective like you mentioned, but they aren‚Äôt ideally meant for regular use. You might want to discuss preventive medications with your doctor, such as beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, or antiepileptic drugs, which can help reduce the frequency of attacks. Dietary changes are important, too. You‚Äôve already taken a great step by removing sugar from your diet. Other adjustments to consider include staying well-hydrated, avoiding common trigger foods like caffeine, chocolate, processed foods, and foods high in histamine like aged cheeses and cured meats, and eating small, regular meals to stabilize blood sugar levels. Lifestyle modifications can make a big difference here as well. Stress management techniques like meditation, yoga, and deep-breathing exercises can help manage stress, which is a common trigger for migraines. My migraines are also my excuse for prioritizing looonnnggg sleep sessions üò¥ üòÖ because maintaining a regular sleep schedule and ensuring adequate sleep is imperative in reducing the likelihood of attacks. Regular, moderate exercise can help reduce the frequency and severity of migraines, too. Although it‚Äôs important to be cautious of overexertion. Some people find relief with supplements like riboflavin (vitamin B2), magnesium, and coenzyme Q10. I personally don't, but to each their own, everyone has to find what works well for them. Keeping a migraine diary can also be useful. Tracking your symptoms, diet, sleep patterns, and other potential triggers can help identify patterns and triggers specific to you, which can be valuable in managing the condition. Hopefully, this was some helpful baseline information that you can use as a jumping-off point if you ever find out that you're one of the few other unlucky suckers like me who are blessed with this misunderstood nightmare.

I have eagle oil the lavender/eucalyptus kind, that I put on my temples and an eye mask massager. I have two migraine ice caps. After my eye mask runs its course. Then I put the ice pack on my head and my neck and lay there with the covers off in a freezing cold room and stay like that until I'm shivering and then cover up and hopefully pass out for 3-6 hours. I also like digging my finger nails into my forehead and above whichever eye the migraine is over until I pass out. I'd love to get some mask that has nails in it that I could attach to my forehead. When I wake up, I order 2 fish sandwiches with extra cheese and tartar sauce, large fries and a large coke from McDonald's. Not sure if you wanted the full routine but that's what I take for my migraines with aura.

While you wait to see the doctor, you could start the daily supplements shown to support migraine prevention. The most common ones are 400mg of magnesium and 400mg of b2 daily (your pee will be highlighter yellow, that's normal). I also take 400mgbof CoQ10, but the studies that test its efficacy are usually 150-300mg daily. Because you are currently using OTC meds and caffeine, I'd recommend some reading to educate yourself about caffeine and migraine: https://www.reddit.com/r/migraine/search/?q=Caffeine+&type=link&cId=31a89b2a-1f32-4149-9576-8d753e32124b&iId=fe5b5fda-ab10-46c3-8ce7-fadd2e7c91bb For the OTC, make sure you learn about the risk of medication overuse/rebound (because the Tylenol may be increasing your migraine frequency): https://www.reddit.com/r/migraine/search/?q=Moh&type=link&cId=8b74f1bb-cc38-4fa4-9084-2dea50452ef6&iId=8ed832e5-8ebb-4b1f-99a8-ed73b29def1f https://www.reddit.com/r/migraine/search/?q=Rebound&type=link&cId=813c4b40-5b4d-4172-a4f5-a971176f59f9&iId=8416385a-3589-4afd-9f5e-19892873fe72 Finally, it sounds like you got reglan in the ER. You can read about it here and if it sounds like what happened to you, you'll know to tell your doctors in the future that you don't tolerate it: https://www.reddit.com/r/migraine/search/?q=Er+reglan&type=link&cId=34d85fef-7e44-494d-b2a7-a4b46128412a&iId=b3b44960-bca8-4a2e-b8d5-3f9ba702101e

This study isn‚Äôt really looking at the emergency environment where we‚Äôre basically creating, by definition, status migrainosus. This is a key distinction being lost in this thread. It‚Äôs generally accepted in academic American EM that triptans have no good role once this level of migraine is achieved. They work maximally in the prodromal and early phase of headache with poor success once the headache necessitates ED intervention. IV dopamine antagonist with or without Tordaol, Benadryl to alleviate antidopaminergic akithesias, and IV fluids work best. Decadron is great at reducing reoccurrence based on modern literature. Magnesium and valproate are good second-line therapies. I highly recommend reviewing this algorithm posted years ago which nicely details evidence-based guidelines: https://www.painmedicinenews.com/aimages/2015/PMN0915_13.pdf

Some good and bad advice in here. It‚Äôd be nice to see someone from neurology comment on the relevant best modern evidence. No one should be getting SC sumatriptan as a single-agent abortive agent in the ED. As someone who has had migraines, triptans are really only maximally effective during the prodromal and early phase of headache. Once you‚Äôre in an emergency department, antidopamenergics have the best evidence. Compazine/Reglan/Droperidol + Benadryl + 1 L of Cola (NS) FTW. 90% first-strike success rate. Make them call someone to pick them up. Typically 2 hr disposition if you know how to do it correctly. Nurses don‚Äôt want to do an IV? It‚Äôs a migraine. If you‚Äôve never had one (most people who say they have migraines really just have bad headaches), it‚Äôs absolutely cruel and unusual to punt these people to the street without appropriate abortive therapy. I agree with others than 4 mg of slow IVP Decadron should be the last thing the nurses pushes before DCing IV. Finally, the dopamine antagonist fix a ton of other, ahem, secondary patient problems in the ED. I find that a lot of unexplained young female abdominal pain is actually abdominal migraine with near complete and fantastical resolution of all pain following a little squirt of Compazine/Droperidol. It‚Äôs also linked with cyclic vomiting thus why these all work. Excellent satisfaction from patients and you can make a fairly cool exclusionary diagnosis.

Reasons to consider for Botox 1.Wrinkle Reduction - Botox effectively reduces the appearance of dynamic wrinkles, such as crow's feet, frown lines, and forehead lines, by temporarily relaxing the facial muscles that cause them. 2.Non-Surgical Solution - Botox is a non-surgical procedure, offering a quick and relatively painless solution with minimal downtime compared to more invasive cosmetic procedures like facelifts. 3.Medical Benefits **Migraine Relief:** Botox has been approved for the treatment of chronic migraines, providing relief for many patients by reducing the frequency and severity of headache attacks. **Hyperhidrosis Treatment:** It effectively treats hyperhidrosis (excessive sweating), particularly in the underarms, hands, and feet, by blocking the nerves that stimulate sweat glands. **Muscle Spasm Control:** Botox can be used to treat muscle spasms and disorders such as cervical dystonia, blepharospasm, and other conditions characterized by involuntary muscle contractions. 4.Quick and Convenient- The procedure typically takes about 10-15 minutes, making it convenient for those with busy schedules. **Immediate Results:** While the full effects may take a few days to appear, some improvement can be seen within 24-48 hours, offering relatively quick results. 5.Boosts Confidence- By smoothing out wrinkles and lines, Botox can enhance a person's overall appearance, leading to increased self-confidence and improved self-esteem. 6.Customizable Treatments - It can be tailored to individual needs and desired outcomes, allowing for a natural look that maintains facial expressiveness. 7.Safe and Effective - Botox is one of the most extensively studied and tested cosmetic treatments, with a strong safety profile and a long history of successful use in both cosmetic and medical applications. hi! I work for a virtual neurology clinic that specializes in migraine. happy to answer questions. Cove is great if you need simple migraine acute medications (for attacks) or basic migraine preventive medications (daily meds to manage the disease). All care is provided by text messaging. The clinic where I work is more geared toward patients at the more severe end of the spectrum who need specialized care (but we also treat episodic migraine). In addition to headache specialist appointments by zoom, you get care coaching, a care curriculum, care plans, and a care team to help you along the way. Both are great options depending on your need. If you just need a prescription refill and you know what you need, Cove is excellent. If you need more hand-holding and specialized care, Neura Health is a better option. Hope that helps!

Blue to the sky‚Ä¶ July 30, 2024 ~ k I was on the phone with my friend last night who lives 40ish minutes away from me. She recently started a new migraine medication that is an injection and, last night, started a higher dose. As I was talking to her, she started coughing and wheezing and I was getting really concerned so I grabbed my purse and left my house and started heading towards her house, (probably faster than the speed limit). Anyway, when I got to her, her blood pressure was 90/50 and she looked terrible. I have epi pens at home and have a general idea on how to use them, and thankfully, she has them too. I know the rule of, ‚Äúblue to the sky, orange to the thigh.‚Äù Meaning the blue part goes up and the orange part is the stabby part. I stabbed her with her epi pen and drove her the five minutes to the emergency room, (it would have honestly taken longer to get an ambulance and get to the er than it would have to just get her into my car). So yeah. Fun times. She‚Äôs still feeling a little gross this morning, but her PCP gave her some more steroids and I thought she will be okay. Whew! Photo by me. Like someone else said, I also track my migraines using Migraine Buddy. The interface can be overwhelming during excruciating migraines, but my previous doctor and boss loved that I could send them YTD pdfs of all my migraine entries. I don't remember anything memorable about those tests. I don't think it helps that I often get a milder version of the lightheadedness for hours at a time/sometimes it's just an entire day, so often I have symptoms already going into the test and it's harder to tell if it's causing anything. But I know it didn't cause me to faint or feel extremely sick. Another problem is that I often have the "whitecoat" syndrome (or whatever it's actually called) where my blood pressure will rise when I'm at doctors because I stress about their offices (and especially blood tests, after the fainting and bad experiences with people getting angry at me for being nervous.) More than a few times I've had really low blood pressure at home (checked with a wrist cuff, back when I had one) but at the doctor my bp is "great" because it's raised enough it's in the lower end of healthy range. The lowest it ever got at home was 85/something and I was feeling very tired, lightheaded, and cold at the time, but we didn't go to the doctor since money was bad. That first link, I don't remember any sort of cognitive test in between - I just remember them asking me to lay down and taking my bp, then having me sit up and stay still then taking it again, and I'm pretty sure they had me stand then took it one more time. They asked me if I felt like I was going to faint and how I was feeling at each point but that was it. I know I've had three doctors do it the same way and it definitely felt like a quick/easy test. My primary doctor referred me to a neurologist, but I had a really rough experience with him - despite the nurse taking my symptoms down and going over things with me for almost the whole appointment time, he came in asking me about "former conditions" I'd never said, cut me off when I was explaining my symptoms, said it was likely migraine-related but we'd do an EEG to check for seizures and get me on migraine medication. The EEG was clean and I ended up not taking the medication because it was apparently one that could cause serotonin syndrome taken with an unrelated medicine I was already on - didn't learn that until I went to the pharmacy to get it and after that I didn't really feel comfortable seeing him anymore. My primary said she was sorry it went badly and said if I could find another neurologist I liked in my insurance, she'd get me a referral, I just.. have had no clue what sort of specialist to see and many are booked for so far out that I'd be seeing them when I no longer had that insurance since my plan is going to end next year. I don't have a Facebook, but I'll see if I can find autonomic specialists in my area (and plan) or if she has one she'd want to refer me to. Thank you so much for sending this stuff as it gives me a little direction when I'm feeling very overwhelmed and lost and tired.

Oh my gosh!! Honestly that is so typical of neurologists üôÑ if you can definetly switch. Getting a second, third, fourth opinion seems essential for TN or most invisible illnesses unfortunately :( Idk how much time you‚Äôve spent on the forum, BUT i have posted a lengthy ‚Äúhow i got out of pain‚Äù I‚Äôll copy/paste the text below! (Couldn‚Äôt figure out how to copy/paste the link on my phone lol) ________________________________________ What helped me to be pain-free (TN2) I have been on this forum for a couple of years and just commenting. But I thought it might be helpful to share how I became pain-free - the meds, pain management procedures I found most helpful, the surgeries I did, the kind of doctors I saw, and the neurosurgeon I saw. Unfortunately, it seems you have to go through/fail other body systems - ENT, Dental, etc - for insurance and doctors to establish that you have TN. Then you have to fail noninvasive treatments for TN - medications (seizure meds), nerve blocks, etc - for insurance and doctors to refer you to neurosurgery. Once you do several procedures can help eliminate/greatly reduce the pain. But you have to find a neurosurgeon who is not a square. This is all doable when you know the system and have support. **Quick Summary:** 28F, TN2 from 2014 - 2020, Nerve pain-free since 2020 **Initial Pain** The pain started at 19. It felt like thumbs were digging into my temples. Constant. As soon as I woke up till I fell asleep. **Navigating a Diagnosis** ***ENT)*** I first went to ENT since I felt a pressure pain sensation. I had 3 ENT surgeries - deviated septum, turbinate reduction, and sinus surgery. Although all of these might of been necessary surgeries none of these helped reduce the constant pain I had. ENT was ruled out. ***NEURO)*** Went to neurology and was prescribed an anti-seizure medication. The following meds were ruled out because could not tolerate the side effects of the following meds or they did not touch my pain - Keppra, Tegretol, Trileptal, Gapentin, Lyrica. I found the most relief with Topomax. I would not say my pain disappeared with this medication, rather it dulled the intensity. This was helpful. Although my pain was regarded as a migraine or NDPH - A new daily persistent headache - I still needed topomax to somewhat function. Neuro is a must. ***DENTAL)*** after one neurosurgery team told me I didn‚Äôt have TN they diagnosed me with TMJ... bless their hearts. ***PAIN MANAGEMENT)*** lidocaine occipital injections = never worked on me occipital nerve block = worked for a while then stopped Botox for migraines = worked and they can do the occipital region, the neck, TMJ sphenopalatine ganglion (SPG) block = worked super well -(but they can do it x-ray guided or non x-ray guided w/cotton swabs... don‚Äôt do the cotton swabs doesn‚Äôt work as accurately) Marinol, a synthetic cannabinoids used to treat neuropathic chronic pain = worked very well. Gave me relief. And I could take 5mg or 10mg for bad pain. I felt safer knowing it was doctor-prescribed. And I think it establishes that you do have neuropathic pain. And my insurance did cover it. Lidocaine patches = worked well when my pain changed. I would put them on my face. Doctor prescribed. *Kind of doctor you should find for this = board-certified physical medicine and rehabilitation (PM&R) physician with board-certified sub-specialization in pain medicine* **Pain Change** Around 2018 my pain evolved. I began having facial sensations - wind, makeup, smiling hurting my face. And I could no longer manage my pain anymore. The meds and pain management procedures stopped working (quality and quantity) and I was becoming non-functional. This is when we started looking toward surgery **SURGERY** I saw Dr. Michael Lim, Chair of the Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford Medicine known around the world for his expertise in the care of people with trigeminal neuralgia. [https://med.stanford.edu/profiles/238246](https://med.stanford.edu/profiles/238246) He did two Microvascular Decompressions and a Rhizotomy on the left side a year later. My images did not show signs of compression. But Dr. Lim said he would still do the surgery because he found that even combing the trigeminal nerve helped patients with their pain. But once he was in my brain he saw the compressed nerve. So if your images are negative that isn‚Äôt the be-all end-all. **Conclusion** I feel like it seems I am put together by this post. But I was a mess during this time. I was depressed and so angry. And that part of TN or chronic illness isn‚Äôt talked about enough. Heck, it isn‚Äôt researched enough to even be talked about. But It is really hard. And it is hard to trust doctors who have no idea what this pain feels like. What this pain takes away. I hope this information helps. Because there is light at the end of this horrific tunnel. I promise.

It depends on the place you‚Äôre going to, but it‚Äôs usually just a combination of things like NSAIDs (Toradol, Tylenol, etc.), Bendadryl, caffeine, anti-nausea meds, and magnesium. Sometimes they can give you triptans if it‚Äôs early enough in the migraine and you‚Äôre not already on them. But no, they aren‚Äôt just handing you opioids if you tell them you have migraine pain. I‚Äôve never gone for something like this myself because a good PCP/specialist will give you prescriptions for most of that for home if you ask. I already have a couple of triptans, a high-dose NSAID, anti-nausea meds, magnesium, etc.

I'm someone who has had headaches my whole life and they got worse with every year until about 12 years ago where I had a series of one six month log migraine or a 5-month long migraine to the point where I was seeing some of the top specialists in the US for it including being hospitalized and getting a PIC line with medications to try to break it. During this process I ended up going to the emergency room in the desperate plea to have some relief has nothing was working I was given an IV cocktail of reglan and toradol. What happened was a huge anxiety attack I could not feel any kind of relief I felt panic and fear like the walls were closing around me and I told them if they didn't take the IV out I would take it out myself and I basically ran out of the ER. It took me months to figure out what happened and why. And it was later my neuro gave me a pill called compazine and it started to produce similar effects within me, extreme agitation and since I could not settle myself and an extreme anxiety. Also the only other thing that seemed to help my migraines was Benadryl but Benadryl along with most cold medications will give me severe restless leg. And the only other time I remembered having RLS was in puberty and then it went away after some time. As I was researching what was going on with me in these medications I came to learn that some anti-emetics and some antipsychotics which are sometimes used to try to break a migraine are dopamine scrubbers and I started to ask myself why am I like the one percent or 2% of people to have this effect? Does it mean that maybe I have less free-range dopamine than other people in my system? I had long suspected that I had ADHD but I always felt I was masking well enough to often cover for it but as I started to move into perimenopause the effects got so bad that it almost made me lose complete control of my business The mistakes I was making and my lack of attention to details even when I was really trying and had plan a plan b and plan c feel safe knowing that these are problems of mine we're not working. At the age of 43 I finally got the diagnosis and got on Adderall and it was unlike anything I had ever experienced in my life. All of the reading social anxiety that I had where I felt I just was never good enough and that others might be harmful to me and this persistent social anxiety that has been the bane of my existence went away that noise went completely away for the first time in my life. I was so surprised by that effect I had no idea that the medication would even touch that I was seeking out the medication just to stop losing everything and forgetting everything. The other thing it did is it turned the volume down to my emotions I remember my ex-husband saying things like you can think about something and then have a feeling about that thing and that sounded impossible to me because inside of me was like that Muppet character animal he played the drums, that my emotions were so fast and so loud I was overtaken by them there was no space between thoughts and feelings feelings were a storm I had to endure. And I felt as much a victim of those as I'm sure everyone around me did but with the medication the range of those feelings the rage, the despair, the ideations it all quieted I had no idea the medication would help me with this. With the medication I began to be consistent in my habits for the first time in my life and be able to remember things and catch my mistakes as I'm making them. Losing my things was not a constant and persistent problem but a once in a while problem. As a result my business began to do very well and I published my book which one a major award. I'm by no means "cured" perfect but I think about who I was for most of my life and how I was blamed for how I was or shunned for how I was or scapegoated or just avoided and I think many of us have that persistent innate brokenness within us that I had no I just couldn't help it and I didn't have the words to even understand what was wrong for most of my life. I will never be good at math I love the concept the details always upend me. I will always forget things I will always forget to shut the kitchen cabinets I will get my names wrong I will forget important dates. But now that I have a more adequate supply of dopamine it makes me realize with great clarity how much easier it is to have that appropriate amount and how my whole life I was judged as if I was the same as everyone else. And the good news is I got medication that has practically eliminated my migraines due to world class biologics. I am on Adderall which has been an absolute miracle in game changer for me, and I'm on hormones to help with my perimenopausal swings and with these three things taken care of for the first time in my life ever I have felt okay I have felt stable I have felt comfortable within myself and all of that all of that came from asking myself why some of these migraine medications were throwing me into panic attacks. And I wonder if anyone else here has a similar story.

I have migraine with aura and use HRT. My neurologist said it‚Äôs safe. HRT has drastically reduced the number of migraines I get (I‚Äôve had 2 in the past 12 months.) More info: https://www.womens-health-concern.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/18-WHC-FACTSHEET-Migraine-and-HRT-NOV2023-B.pdf

It's a miracl drug ,for me. I've had chronic migraines since I was a kid. Over the years I was pretty much incapacitated with daily,one sided head pain and all kinds of tag along symptoms. Throughout the years other issues were added. Shingles in my ear (same side)and bells palsey. A TBI .The pain was non-stop day in,day out. Down the road I was diagnosed with one of the top 3 worst pain conditions known to man (it's not just my opinion. It's documented ) Trigeminal Neuralgia. Tried several meds with no luck. TN fell by the wayside. I spent most of my adult life searching for something to help my migraines.After taking every migraine med available I recently saw a new to the practice aprn. She ordered pregabalin(Lyrica). I told her I was on Neurontin for many years when young . I had to stop it because it ruined my liver. It also didn't help. I started at 75mg 2 times per day. Titrated to 100mg 2 times per day. I couldn't believe it. My face,ear and head pain eased up. Soon I started having breakthrough pain. I asked to do 3 per day instead of increasing the mgs. Now I take 3 per day . I can't believe I suffered that horrible pain 24/7 365,since 1989. The rest of my chronic conditions and pain still keep me down but I can't put into words how thankful I am to be able to mostly control that particular pain. Pregabalin is the one and only best medicine for T N. Now I've also gained control over my migraines,with the right meds. What a difference when a diagnosis is aknowledged and treated with the right medication. I am so grateful.... Now we need to work on addressing our chronic pain by gaining less stressful access to the medication that helps,when all else fails...
