Over two years ago I (35f) went to the doctors as I had not had a period in months and I had put over 2 stone in weight on in as many months (even pregnant I have never weighed this much). He sent me for blood tests and said my thyroid was 136 to take 50mcg levothyroxine and my periods would come back I would lose weight but that I would be on it for life. He also referred me to an Endocrinologist. A month or so later it had come down considerably to around 40s and then a few weeks again to about 12, after this he told me to stop taking it and that was that. I had not had a period I had not lost weight. He then sent me for PCOS tests but I confirmed I aready was diagnosed with this 20 years ago he sent me anyway scan and blood test confirmed I have PCOS. I also started getting what I can only describe as a cluster headache or migraine (it is behind one eye and down to my top teeth) another doctor prescribed sumatriptan which worked. Otherwise I would be in so much pain I would take painkillers and cry mself to sleep for 24 hours. Anyway I still have the same problem with my periods, looking at the pattern it seems to be that I don't have a period for roughly 6 months then I have maybe 1 a month for 2-3 months in a row then they stop again. I have a family history or uterine cancer (nana at 30 years old full hysterectomy), endometriosis and PCOS my aunt has similar symtoms to me and also had a full hysterectomy at 37. However my mum has no issues and is over 50 not even perimenopausal. I take no medication currently my last blood test showed thyroid at 3 and I have a headache that I have been in bed with for 2 days I have been keeping up with the gym (mostly running and swimming) and watching what I eat and have lost no weight that I gained from 2 years ago. I went to the Endocrinologist after an 18 month wait, they said they didn't know why I was there as my thyroid was in normal range and told my doctor to refer me to a gyno which after waiting for 5 months into a 12month list the receptionist told me he hadn't gotten round to so I have a doctors appointment next week and he will refer me from there. I know this is a lot and I don't expect anyone to read it however I don't know where else to turn to and I feel like I am lost as to what to even suggest to my doctors, if I suggest nothing he is happy to just send me home and I can't live like this surely going months without a period and then the weight not changing when I eat well and work out is a cause for concern plus the headaches

Have a pre-existing headache or migraine disorder Headache and or migraines on 15 or more days a month use of the following medications at the following rates for over three months **For those who only use one medication out of the following list- use these numbers** 15 or more days using acetaminophen, ASA and NSAIDs 10 or more days using triptans, and combination analgesics (excedrin, &or caffeine OTC meds) 8 or more days using ergotamines 3 or more days of opiods or butilbital (fiorcet) **if you use two or more of the medications listed above you can get MAH by simply medicating 10 or more days out of the month (a day is counted if you use at least one medication at least one dose)** 50% of all chronic migrainers have MAH and of those- a WHOPPING 50-75% will no longer be chronic after treating their MAH. (Which is why I‚Äôm always on one about it.. that‚Äôs a lot of people who could find relief!!!)

I am one of the 1.1 billion people who has migraines! I normally make octopus content but as someone who has lived her whole life with chronic migraines I‚Äôd like to do some awareness and education on the neurological disease in addition to my marine biology content! Migraines are horribly debilitating and most often they are described as laying in a dark room/bathroom with no sound and throwing up all day. Lasting days to weeks. What is frequently not talked about is those who experience chronic migraines and how different our migraines become after years of an endless migraine! I am currently seeing reduction in my chronic migraines for the first time in my life due to my ADHD diagnosis and medication. Untreated ADHD is a known comorbodity with migraine. Pushing for a diagnosis in my mid-20‚Äôs has started to dramatically change my life. And its an answer i had to find on my own! #migraine #chronicillness #fypp #foryou

Who told you they were a cure? Migraine has no cure or magic pill. I‚Äôm sorry that your care team was not fully transparent with you. Also, med trialing is a three-month process. You will not know if a medication is fully successful until after around three months. The signs to look for are - reduction in migraine or headache days - reduction in symptoms - reduction in attack duration - better response to acute medication You are SO new to the medication trialing process. And there are tons of meds available for you to try. But remember that meds don‚Äôt work on their own and we have to do our job to help them work more effectively: - maintain sleep/caffeine/meal schedule - meditation/progressive muscle relaxation - neuromodulation devices - stress management - nutritious/filling meals - maintaining good hydration - exercise once you get to a point where you can tolerate it As i said, migraine is a life-long disease. The best we can hope for is remission. There is no cure. You can choose to let that reality defeat you or you can let it motivate you to fight for a better quality of life. I‚Äôve given you lots of good tips from someone who not only works as a headache clinic but has been living with incredibly disabling daily migraine attacks longer than I‚Äôd like. If I let taking a single daily medication get me down, i would have no hope. We have to hold hope. We have to look for the positives. Research shows that the more positive we are, the better outcomes we can have.

I've personally been diagnosed with them, and your description sounds extremely similar to my circumstances. There is no specific test for the disease, so it's a diagnosis of exclusion (i.e. you have to rule out everything else out first, which is what it sounds like you've pretty much accomplished). Thankfully, they are essentially treated just like "normal" migraines with the use of migraine medications like triptans or TCA's.

I have been a Kratom user for 7-8yrs. 7-20gpd. 10years ago, when I first researched Kratom, I was under the impression that Kratom was in addictive. I eventually decided to try it in place of my opioid prescription for severe hip pain. Oh boy was I wrong. It most definitely is addictive. I'm noticing there is so much more info on the subject now, than it use to be..... Anywho, so I accidentally got myself addicted to Kratom and didn't even notice until 6 days ago, when I was giving no choice but to go without. But 24hrs, I was sweating but freezing, jumping and jittering. My mind was all over the place. Body hurts so bad. By 48 hrs, it was all amplified by 10. I couldn't sleep because I couldn't stop moving. Exhausted, yet wide awake. I finally smoked some THC, I got 2hrs of sleep. By 72hrs, it hit even deeper. The brain fog was so bad too. I'd be in mid sentence and forgot what I was talking about. Not to mention I was babysitting for my best friend while she was on her honeymoon. It was awful. The fourth day, I was super fatigued and lethargic. Felt like I had the flu on steroids. Sneezy, nose and eyes watering, my limbs were jumping all over the place. I had someone offer to bring me some Kratom to stop the withdrawal. I told them "no. I've made it this far, I'm slaying this demon". I was so proud of me in that moment. Another night of 2hr sleep. Day 5, I still felt a little fatigued. Not bad. Cravings weren't as bad. Migraine from out of this world. Still, no sleep. Had someone else offer to help me out to stop the withdrawal. Again, I denied the offer. Another night of 2hr sleep. Ugh. Now I'm on day 6. So far I feel ok. Small headache. Body so exhausted. But my spirit is up and happy...... During this time what has helped me is having a focus on taking care of these children. Luckily, one is much older and was super helpful around the house and with his younger sibling. They knew nothing. I told them I caught a bug, and I'd still cook, clean, sat outside with them. I played it cool. I reached out to those I trust the most for support, as soon as I recognized that I was withdrawaling. They were helpful, and right by their phones at all times. Vitamin C packets, massive amounts of water, coffee, Motrin, Excedrin, hot baths, and THC at night time, helped a lot...... No, this isn't the first time I've been through something like this. But it's been a long time. 15yrs long time. I was addicted to opioids in my past. My reasoning for wanting to trade my prescriptions for Kratom. I thought because it was natural, I'd be good....... I say all of this to say, if you are taking yourself off of Kratom and are currently going through withdrawals, just know you aren't alone. There is light at the end of the tunnel. Don't give up. You can do this. YES it does get better.

It's had to know exactly the correct answer to what to do now. If you know for sure you are susceptible to rebound, you should stop all NSAIDs, analgesics (like Tylenol), and the triptan. But some people don't seems to have a problem with rebounds and may need to continue to treat a longer migraine. If it were me and I was new to all this and didn't know for sure if the ibuprofen was causing a problem, I might try to treat for another 24-36 hours and see if it gets better. Did your doctor say anything about max dosing for the zomig? Some doctors don't want you using it more than 2x/week. Mine said no more than 3 days in a row for me, but that was based on my particular pattern of migraine frequency and duration. Some other things to try that might help would be a big dose of electrolytes (especially sodium and magnesium) and fluid, and/or icing or heat depending on what feels good. Or you could try the ER and see if the cocktail is helpful.

I don‚Äôt know why you‚Äôre getting downvoted. Zonfran does cause headache, this is a well established side effect of ondansetron and other drugs in the same class (IIRC granisetron was pulled from the market for this very side effect). It‚Äôs an antagonist at receptors for the neurotransmitter triptans are agonists at so the basic science is plausible (not the same serotonin subtype but still, biological systems are messy). Zofran is very safe in general but just because it‚Äôs the go-to drug to throw at nausea in most patients doesn‚Äôt mean it has a valuable role in migraine management. The level of evidence for anti-dopaminergic antiemetics is much better.

>The differences are statistically significant, but given that the intake of EPA and DHA would essentially skyrocket if you went from 0 fish to 2 servings per week Fish aren't the exclusive way to obtain those fatty acids in the blood. Additionally, serum levels or blood cell levels are just what's in immediate circulation, it doesn't tell you much about tissue levels in for example the brain or retina. Even so, red blood cell membrane levels are more reflective of habitual intake than serum levels per se. Serum levels aren't the full picture. It's just a snapshot in time with no reference to utilisation. Imagine I have a blunt with top quality Afghani kush, but I don't smoke it, it just sits there and gathers dust and mould. My neighbour also has a spliff, but he's smoking and replacing his spliff every single day. Based on information that we both have a doobie each in our houses, and no other information at all, you'd be pressed to predict that we'll have the same amount of THC in our blood, while in reality the level of weed we have in our houses is not at all indicative of our usage of said weed. So it's not even impossible to have similar level of o3s in the serum while experiencing a relief from migraine by taking o3s. Lastly, epa and dha are not storage forms of o3, the closest to storage form of both is dpa, that that has been shown to increase with o3 supplementation. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4555130/

Yup, I know I‚Äôve got a migraine coming on because I first get a blind spot in my vision almost like I stared at a bright light too long, then tv static snakes that slowly expand, then slowly move out of my field of vision, then the headache starts. So I‚Äôve got about a 30 minute warning before the pain starts. The brain fog is immediate though, and lasts all day and into the next. I would recommend anyone who gets migraines regularly to either start taking daily allergy meds or go to an allergist and get tested. I never thought those two things could be connected, but in my case I‚Äôd start getting migraines in the spring and they‚Äôd go through the summer, usually one or two a week on average. I made the connection to the allergy season and started taking Flonase and Zyrtec (after my first migraine of the year) and I haven‚Äôt had another one in about 5 months. This time last year I was up to probably 30. I‚Äôm not a doctor, and there‚Äôs no guarantee it‚Äôll work for you, but it did for me and I can‚Äôt tell you how happy I am about that. And after seeing the even more extreme effects allergies had on a friend of mine (Parkinson‚Äôs-like symptoms) I tell everyone who‚Äôs having weird medical problems they can‚Äôt figure out: maybe you‚Äôve got some allergies you aren‚Äôt aware of.

hi! I'm sorry that your doctor hasn't been more helpful. Is your doctor a GP or a neurologist? Do you have symptoms beyond dizziness? If you have vestibular migraine, meclizine won't be helpful (benzos are more effective for vestibular migraine). Additionally, a triptan taken this late in the attack won't be helpful either. If your provider thinks that you have vestibular migraine, the emergency room won't be very helpful unless you provide them with a protocol of what you need (ie: doctor's note outlining intravenous medication, etc). Migraine attacks, left untreated, can last 4-72hrs. If they extend beyond that, it's considered status migrainosus which requires stronger interventions like steroids or intravenous medication. [here's a post we made about how to decide if you're having a migraine emergency](https://www.neurahealth.co/blog/what-to-do-when-in-a-migraine-emergency). I hope that it's helpful for you. And [here's a good video by Dr Teixido about managing vestibular migraine](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=24tEzO4vQWc&ab_channel=MichaelTeixidoMD). I personally think he has one of the best approaches to treating the disease.

I'm so glad to hear you have a team and you're not going into this alone or with a single rogue neurologist with no idea. I've really heard some horror stories about treatment and patient care of HM patients. I had to wait 6 months to even see a neurologist after my first HM attack, which was so difficult. I know how it feels to not be able to move, and feel like it's making it worse. If you can't exercise, don't be too hard on yourself. Your body might need the rest more than you think! HM is so hard on your body and mind, the brain fog is intense. In the meantime, make sure you have blue-light filters enabled on your devices. I also have a physical blue light shield on my computer called an Occushield- it's amazing. A kindle is great too- no blue light and you can increase the font so very migraine friendly. I also recommend having your eyes tested if you haven't in the past 12 months to make you have the right glasses, or see if you need them. Little changes can make a big difference, good luck!!

i also am a side effect magnet and i had a hellscape of a time trialing other meds, but Emgality has been amazing for me! no side effects and it basically halved my migraine frequency and helped minimize the severity of attacks. it's not a perfect fix but i feel that it's given me my life back more than any other med. so i'm hopeful you have a good experience with it! some advice: the injections hurt more than their tutorial video makes it seem, lol. i'm not normally uncomfy with needles and i've got a ton of tattoos with no problem but the auto-injector is pretty nasty. in my experience the pre-filled syringe is a bit less painful. that said, either of them are still totally doable with some prep. i find taking it out of the fridge for at least a couple hours before helps cause if it's still cold it'll hurt more. ice the injection site well, swab with alcohol and make sure that it's dried before you inject. taking some painkillers before can help. i also take allergy meds (zyrtec) a couple hours before injecting as that's helped with injection site irritation, but i have super sensitive skin so that might just be a me issue. best part is once it's done you don't have to think about it for a month! best of luck with it!

Few issues: 1. Cravings are a symptom of migraine disease, especially during prodrome, suggesting the migraine attack has already started. 2. The role of neurotransmitters and this common prodrome symptom is not something I'm aware of. Do you have any sources to support this? 3. There is no such thing as migraine due to reactive hypoglycemia. If someone has true postprandial hypoglycemia, further investigations are needed to determine why they have it. Gastric bypass? NIPHS? Etc. 4. As for additives and preservatives being a migraine trigger... anything can be a migraine trigger. Anything that throws a patient's homeostasis off can be a trigger. While there are common triggers, there are also very unique triggers people may have. Even food consistency may be a trigger for some. The goal is to use lifestyle modifications, preventives, and abortives properly to make those triggers matter less. Leading a life with the least morbidity possible is the goal. 5. There is more evidence for a keto diet, high omega-3 diet, or a Mediterranean diet than a low glycemic index diet. 6. A healthy diet and lifestyle is definitely important in terms of migraine management and if a low glycemic diet helps you do that then great. For others, other healthy lifestyle measures will likely be part of their plan.

No, it's definitely not a you problem. I don't have any research at hand, and I will go down a wormhole for a few hours if I start looking for some, which is my natural inclination, so I apologize. I do know that having ADHD makes people more prone to all types of headaches, partially because we have trouble managing things like regular sleep schedules, eating regularly, remembering to hydrate, that can trigger a headache or a migraine. Also a lot of ADHD medications have headaches as side effects. However, if you read through threads here about symptoms people get with a migraine, losing the ability to focus is and think clearly is a very common one, even for people without ADHD. I can only speak from personal experience, but if I get a bad migraine, even if I'm medicated, my ADHD symptoms change from struggling to control my focus, but being able to make some choices about what actions I take or where I point my attention, to where it just feels like I'm on a ride, with my focus just going from one thing to the next and I can't choose what to do with my time or really even think in a linear way. Then the day is suddenly finished and I have no idea what I did with it, except jump from one stimuli to the next. Also, in this state, I would much rather be alone, because it's so difficult to string together coherent sentences and be normal with people. And, yeah, it feels a little crazy, honestly, so I understand why you felt that way.

Got it. Unfortunately, a derm won't know the PREEMPT protocol the same way your neurologist will and you won't have the same level of success (been in a similar situation but a neurotologist did mine in a moment of desperation instead of a headache specialist and the results were awful). Just because someone knows how to perform Botox for some procedures doesn't mean they know ALL the procedures and PREEMPT is very specific and requires training. Only if you feel comfortable sharing, who's currently treating you? Is it a general neurologist or a headache specialist? And, again only if you're comfortable, where do you receive in-patient infusions? Our situations are somewhat parallel (daily pain & attacks, unsuccessful medication trials, etc) but it seems that our quality of care and provider communication differ dramatically. So I want to have an understanding of whether you're seeing a headache specialist (a neurologist with a fellowship in migraine & headache medicine) or a general neurologist. [Have you looked into Dr Voigt](https://www.lsuhn.com/amy-voigt-md/)? She's who I would see if I lived in your region. When you're complex and refractory like us, pretty much always go with someone who is Jefferson-trained. (sorry - I prowled your comments to see what part of the country you were in! Please don't think I'm a creep but your neuro's suggestion is highly suspect and worrisome!)

Hi Y‚Äôal‚Äù. (I‚Äôm going to explain it in and out so can be triggering to some) I‚Äôm 30F. I‚Äôve had migraine for more than half my life - 17 years and counting. I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs been more than that, since before that I didn‚Äôt feel it serious enough to ask my parents to take me to the doctor. It‚Äôs always been the severe, chronic episodes of strong tingling starting from the finger tips of the one side of my body, goes up from the arm till the shoulder, covering half my chest, then half the neck, up till the head, including the tongue. Immediately after would follow the visual effects - the bright spot of light turning into a big web covering the entire eye. All the drama used to go on for about an hour and a half or so and then it stops. Only, to be followed by a pulsating, throbbing headache. Mostly on the opposite side of where all this other drama was going on. This started when I was 13. Went on till 15 days back. I would love to share with you all that I used to think that my trigger was acidity - and that I only have to regulate the food I eat and that my migraine will stop. And tell you what. It in fact did control to a larger extent. My attacks which happened 3-4 in a week, reduced to one per quarter or once every two months at max. Until a fortnight back. Things have been really tough and I had been under a lot of stress of late. That said - I witnessed a constant sensory aura, no visual one, one without a migraine for over a day and to rule out the possibility of a stroke, I went to a neurologist. Got a plain MRI, some blood tests and an EEG done. My MRI result states - Minimally hyperintense subependymal nodules in the lateral margin of left lateral ventricle without any blooming heterotopic grey matter nature. Rest all results are fine. The doctor has prescribed a preventive migraine medication and one to neutralise the effects of an ongoing attack. The problem is - I‚Äôm on this medication since last 15 days. The medication that I‚Äôm supposed to have whenever I get a migraine, I‚Äôm having it regularly because I‚Äôm having one or the other symptom daily while consuming the preventive medication. The other problem is that these medications have made me really lethargic. I feel sleepy during the day and sleepless during the night. My sinuses feel a constant pressure now which wasn‚Äôt the case before. I have sensory auras every other day and a constant headache every 2-3 days. Also these medications have made my stomach so warm and more acidic than ever. Can anyone please relate with me and tell me that it‚Äôll all be fine. I don‚Äôt know if anyone can understand what I‚Äôm going through. Also if there‚Äôs a cure to stop all this? Please?üôè

I have PCOS. I was diagnosed at 16 and put on a birth control pill. As soon as I started taking it, I started having these migraines (minus speech issues). I knew people could get really bad headaches called migraines, but that was all I knew. I didn‚Äôt know what made a migraine a migraine. I‚Äôd never heard of an aura. I didn‚Äôt know why sometimes I would be going about my day, and suddenly not be able to see. It took me years to learn what it was. I was afraid to tell anyone, and kind of afraid I was dying. No, that‚Äôs not the right way to go about things, but I was a teenage girl and I was scared. At 21, I took a job with a commute, and I knew that if I ever got a headache on the road I‚Äôd be in trouble. I had done some research of my own by that point, and learned that birth control with estrogen gives some women these migraines. I went to the doctor and asked for a progesterone-only pill. Since I started taking it, I‚Äôve had only one migraine. I‚Äôm now 24. Do not be afraid. Do research. When you start a new medication for the first time, ask for a list of possible side effects. Learn how the medication works in your body and what it can affect.

Hello all! Absolutely coming to this thread to see if anyone can put my symptoms together into something or if somehow I genuinely have a variety of issues that are separate. The biggest thing that started in 2019 was something my doctor called intensive hipnic jerks - so what happens is that in my sleep I wake up from that ‚Äúfalling feeling‚Äù but it‚Äôs extremely intense and comes with an immediate panic attack. From that point onward, I‚Äôm very disoriented, hyperventilating, anxious etc and every time I close my eyes it will start all over again. The worst case of this I was awake for four days and having hallucinations from sleep deprivation. This has continued on until present with very little solutions found - currently diagnosed with a panic disorder because of it. It only happens in my sleep or with my really bad migraines. It also has daytime anxiety for all the days it follows until it subsides. In addition to that, I have been diagnosed with ADHD, Asthma, I‚Äôve had migraines since I was 10 (anywhere from 2 hours to the longest one being 13 days). I‚Äôve been diagnosed with IBS and Interstitial Cystitis as well. I very regularly have pretty extreme bloating and never have regular *number twos* unless I take medication for it. This also usually comes with pretty painful abdominal pain. I do also experience pelvic pain most months. I have also been diagnosed as hypermobile in almost all of my joints and I wonder how much is connected to that. My doctor does say I have extra sensitive nerves and very regularly have whole limbs go to sleep very easily, including my right leg not working when my back pain flared up. The back pain theory so far is a slipped disk - xray booked for that I also very regularly have nightmares and used to have nightmares terrors from age two onward. I‚Äôm 29, white female, currently taking: - Sertraline - 75 mg daily - Hydroxyzine - 25-125 mg as needed for sleep and anxiety - Concerta - 27 mg for ADHD - Vitamin D supplement - Magnesium supplement - L-theanine as needed - Lorazepam 1mg as needed - Botox for migraines (hasn‚Äôt helped) I‚Äôm a registered psychotherapist myself, so as far as therapies go, I‚Äôve tried talk therapy, CBT, ACT, DBT skills, EMDR, IFS parts work, somatic work, and I‚Äôm about to try Neurofeedback therapy. I‚Äôve tried physio, acupuncture, massages, lidocaine injections, breast reduction surgery, Botox for migraines and in trap muscles, a whole host of migraine medications. I‚Äôve had the following tests done in the past 5 years and all came back normal unless stated otherwise. - Echocardiogram - ECG - EKG - Extensive testing with internal medicine - two week holter monitor - blood work of almost every type (about to do more) - celiac test was negative - inflammation markers are normal - Thyroid seems to be normal - CT scan was normal - Sleep study came back normal (we were unable to catch the hypnic jerks on the study) - had a gastrointestinal specialist - epilepsy and seizures testing I regularly work out with a blend of weight lifting, cardio, and HIIT. My doctor says my weight and eating is fine! None of my symptoms have ever seemingly been connected to weight or lifestyle in particular. I don‚Äôt drink, I don‚Äôt smoke, I sometimes have some THC and CBD drinks for pain. I am so open to ANY ideas - it has been years of testing with so little answers and it just feels wild to think at least some of them are connected. Happy to answer any questions!! I really appreciate anyone taking the time to read this and any suggestions you may have!

My (29M) girlfriend (26F) of three years is a wonderful girl. I actually plan on proposing for her birthday in the next few months, but there‚Äôs this one issue that has caused a little disturbance. Well, I mean it never was an issue. Until time has caused it to become an everyday issue. My gf ‚ÄúLynn‚Äù and I truly enjoy talking to each other. I am a lot more introverted than her. I enjoy conversation, but really only talk when conversation is initiated with people I don‚Äôt know. Lynn will talk to everybody about everything non stop. Which makes her a good familiar face to lots of people in our mutual friends, community, and other social events. I love that about her. But living with somebody who talks non stop has become emotionally draining. I work a job that is basically non-stop meetings and group efforts over 40 hours a week. Up to 60 some weeks. So I socialize with people all day. When I come home from work, I just want to lay down and decompress for a while. So I go home, kiss her hello, and walk into the other room to read or watch tv. Immediately, Lynn comes up to me and starts ranting or explaining vivid details about her job. Most of the time it‚Äôs not even an issue or a problem, it‚Äôs just describing her work day. Step for step. It goes something like this ‚ÄúSo today, we all had this customer who wanted this. I told them we could do it this way. But ____ came up, and we actually had to try something new. One of my other co workers actually did this today and we talked about _____‚Äù This goes on for maybe 30 min before I try desperately to take a shower and get a second alone. I love her so much, but I spend all day talking non stop and I can‚Äôt continue to talk, or actually LISTEN until I go to bed. What bothers me the most I think is the fact that she talks AT me rather than WITH me. After she talks about her job and she can see I‚Äôm physically uncomfortable, she will say ‚Äúok so how about your day babe?‚Äù I will say one thing. She will listen. Then continue to talk about her job. Or another story from 15 years ago that somehow relate. Then it will snowball into one story about another story and she doesn‚Äôt care if I‚Äôm listening. If I‚Äôm ok. I‚Äôve told her ‚Äúbabe I have a migraine. I can‚Äôt really contribute to this convo anymore‚Äù She will say ‚ÄúOh I‚Äôm sorry babe. Need a Tylenol?‚Äù And then continue the chatter. Same when we go out with her friends. I can never get a word in because she will just talk about their funny memories, or talk about our funny stories without me getting a word in. Yes we will have good discussions. But sometimes, it‚Äôs just too much. I have heard every story about her life, her friends, her ‚Äúfun experiences‚Äù, beef between her softball team mates from middle school. And she will describe it in the worst way possible. Telling every detail of every sentence she says, so a simple 1 min story turns into almost an hour. I really never want to hurt her feelings because when it comes to social batteries, everybody is different. Sometimes when we are in the car together, that‚Äôs when it gets the worst and where I physically feel uncomfortable. Even if it‚Äôs running errands or driving to my parents house an hour away. I will get out of the car ride in almost a frantic run because I feel so suffocated. The other week, we took a road trip to visit her sister and her parents about 4 hours each way. I was exhausted and there was so much traffic. After the first two hours, I could not talk anymore. Or listen. It was non stop stories that ranged from her old neighbors dog, to her old co worker from 10 years ago. Every moment of silence after her 20 min talking I was so anxious. Because I knew I had about 10 seconds maybe 20 until it started again. It made me feel physically nauseous. It was already late at night, and I worked the whole day. So I may have come off a little rude or exhausted. She said ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs wrong? What‚Äôs with the attitude?‚Äù I said I had no attitude I just can‚Äôt engage in conversation now I‚Äôve had a long day. She said ok, And then started talking again within 10 min about something new. She will start the conversation off with something about me or my interests, and then it quickly snowballs into another story with somebody I don‚Äôt care about at all. WIBTA For telling her she talks too much?

Tell your provider you are getting significant pronged exhaustion with Maxalt and see what they suggest. If Maxalt is the only triptan you‚Äôve tried and/or you have the 10mg dose, it could be worth trying a different triptan (there are ~ 9 which are all different) and/or a lower dose (Maxalt comes in 5mg) before giving up on triptans. Otherwise, the next step is likely a CGRP abortive. At least in the U.S. the current options are Ubrelvy (pill), Nurtec (dissolving pill), or Zavzpret (nasal spray - horrid taste but super fast acting and no pill to potentially vomit up). Also, if you have a migraine 2+ days a week, the symptoms are severe, and/or the symptoms don‚Äôt respond well to abortive medications, ensure you are on a migraine preventative. These medications can make migraines less frequent and/or less severe. A less severe migraine is easier to treat.

Wasnt until I was in my 30s at Planned Parenthood in the past 5 years that I was made aware of my birth control being only one of but a very likely cause of my migraine triggers. I got swapped to a Progestin only pill and DEFINITELY noticed a large decrease in number of migraine days within the first month. After 10+ years of seeing a neurologist & having an OBGYN- wasnt until I went to PP that this ‚Äúobvious‚Äù trigger was pointed out.

I would encourage prioritizing seeing a headache specialist over everything. Since you have other nerve issues likely playing into this, you need to be proactive and have a comprehensive plan because allodynia/central sensitization leads to pain responses to basic things like breeze or fabric. Additionally, spend time learning about conditions of central sensitization because your other nerve issues likely are playing into it. (for instance: my allodynia is the result of having several conditions of central sensitization - migraine, fibromyalgia, IBS, etc). The only medication I've personally found to be helpful for my allodynia (and that only was my thermal allodynia, not my static allodynia) is intranasal toradol. I've never found a topical, etc that helps. Botox can dull it for a bit but it rages back. Meditation and biofeedback also have been helpful. When I regularly was doing biofeedback and meditation, my allodynia improved a lot. If you want to see a headache specialist or neurologist quickly (without insurance), I work for a virtual neuro clinic that requires no referral and is as affordable as possible without insurance (Neura Health). Our OOP prices are at least half of what a typical neurology appt would be OOP. We have both headache specialists and general neurology for other conditions like neuropathy, etc. Until you get insurance, I'm sure our providers would develop a treatment plan involving the most appropriate meds from Cost Plus. The other option is Cove which is another telehealth migraine company that treats patients via text message. They have more basic medication options and insurance isn't needed.

That's how aggressive a migraine can get.

I use stations! I have a station in all my rest areas. At my desk, by the couch, and on my nightstand. Each station has everything I would need within arm's reach. So, nail clippers, scissors, USB-C cord, chap stick, eye drops, excedrin and motrin, an eye glass wipe. This way, I'm not taking something from its 'home' and forgetting to put it back, misplacing it. And I'm not putting off doing something I need to do, like clip a hang nail or take a painkiller, which can make these things worse if I don't handle it right away. -- I got this idea from HowtoADHD's YT. She talks about "points of performance" so, having things close to where you would use them. Her example was the kitchen, like keeping everything you need for coffee -- including spoons and things you'd find elsewhere in the kitchen -- by where you make your coffee. I saw this video long before I knew I had ADHD, and used it to adapt my spaces to what she described, so that I had stuff within reach of where I'd need them. Stations as an idea came up for me about a year or two ago, though, a bit after my diagnosis. I also keep a portable station for things I can't get duplicates of easily but also can lose if I'm not careful. It's my ADHD bag, and it has my migraine specs, a battery charger, some lotion, a silent fidget toy, a couple of pens, and a notebook (plus the things in my normal stations.)

I was only diagnosed originally because my doctor did the blood test after I mentioned that I seemed to be having a mild congestion reaction to gluten that I really only noticed because I'm a singer. I had taken to avoiding wheat a few days before a choir concert because it seemed to be impacting my voice -- I would get phlegmy and slightly hoarse but I never noticed any other symptoms. I was shocked when the blood test came back positive. It was only after going GF that I noticed that my occasional migraines with aura went away entirely unless I accidentally got "glutened." The first time I got glutened after going fully GF I had a migraine aura, and then a couple hours later I suddenly had a panic attack in the middle of a choir rehearsal. First time in my life I ever had a panic attack. So apparently gluten makes me anxious and gives me migraines. But I've never had digestive symptoms.

Hello there, I‚Äôm new to the sub. How do I go about getting tested for EDS. Most doctors I speak to about it have either never heard of it or don‚Äôt take me seriously. I cant find much info online about EDS and only know about it through a friend who was diagnosed and my physical therapist who asked if I have it. I‚Äôm not sure how much of this is relevant so I‚Äôll just post some general info about my current conditions. I have severe arthritis and psoriasis. I‚Äôm anemic and hypoglycemic. If I stand up too fast I get lightheaded and blurred vision and have to sit for a while to regain my senses. I‚Äôm hypermobile and I can‚Äôt remember what my physical therapist called it but I have muscle issues and have constant knots in my back, neck, and shoulders. I have stretchy, elastic skin and my veins are all SUPER visible. Almost like my skin is translucent. I get infections easily (some of these symptoms could be because of the injections I take for my arthritis/psoriasis). I have almost constant fatigue/exhaustion. I‚Äôm regularly nauseous. I get headaches probably once a week and a migraine once a month or so. I bruise super easily. Having invisible disabilities is exhausting. But even more exhausting is dealing with doctors who either don‚Äôt care or aren‚Äôt qualified. I was misdiagnosed with my psoriasis 4 times before i found a real answer. 5 doctors couldn‚Äôt figure out what my thrush was until one finally decided to check the side effects of my medicine. I‚Äôve had 4 different rheumatologists and only my most recent one told me to go physical therapy for my hyper mobility, I had no idea the pain I was feeling wasn‚Äôt from my arthritis. I‚Äôm sorry for the long post and rant. I‚Äôm just exhausted. I‚Äôve also had a supposed ‚Äúcold‚Äù for two weeks now and I just wish someone would listen to me when I say that I know it‚Äôs not a cold and there‚Äôs something more going on. Paying $80 for a doctor to tell me to take mucinex is so defeating and sad. TLDR: I think I have EDS? Where do I go to get tested for it?

I have been seeing a specialist for urticaria and have been getting Xolair shots for 3 months now. Before I started Xolair we tried several allergy meds in unison- Allegra for Hives + Ceterizine + Flonase and I was still getting hives every single day so we added the Xolair shots to the mix and I have been hive-free for three full months with the same meds + Xolair! At my last appointment, my allergist suggested seeing how I would do without the Allegra for Hives and the Flonase since I have had no hives after adding Xolair. The day after I stopped these meds I had a terrible 2 day migraine headache the day after stopping and have had lesser headaches every day since. (I haven't had migraines for the past 20 years). I also feel odd and have been a bit sad/moody. It seems crazy that all this could be related to going off allergy medications, but I thought I'd ask to see if anyone else had any similar experiences. I'll call the office tomorrow and check in- just wondering.

I get migraines too, and ever since my ear got eaten by a virus (that would normally have just caused the sniffles, but somehow jumped all my defenses and got into the inner ear in a billion to one event) the migraines have been catastrophic. But! I tried a mega dose of naproxen during a migraine, and after a few migraines, the strength of the migraines reduced a fair bit. My hypothesis is that the defective tissue cooked off, because naproxen at those doses (500mg, can't take anything else with it!) can cause neural damage if it isn't processed fully, such as by receptors that hang on to stuff they shouldn't for too long.

I called them the same day as the horrible appointment was and was told that since I already had a GP, I was at the bottom of the list. Hi there. I am a migraine sufferer normally. I found that my headaches and migraines were at their worst in the second trimester and for the first few weeks of second trimester. I saw an obstetrician as I was given an appointment due to IVF pregnancy and she confirmed that a daily baby aspirin may help. I separately also had an occipital nerve block injection from a neurologist who I had seen about managing my migraines during pregnancy. Whether both of these started to work or whether it was simply the second trimester improvement, I‚Äôm not sure but my migraines did get significant better from around 14 weeks and I‚Äôve had largely none since then which has made such a difference. In terms of coping strategies: ice, dissolvable paracetamol in a full fat coke can help - better to treat early then when one has already set in. I also find salty food like crisps or coconut water can sometimes help. Sorry you‚Äôre going through it - daily headaches are horrible and I find paracetamol doesn‚Äôt do so much for me.

A few years ago, I was reading, and all of a sudden, I just couldn't read. I thought I was having a stroke. But just as I was getting up to go to an emergency room, the migraine pain kicked in, and I understood what was going on. Believe it or not, under the right circumstances, you can feel relieved to get a migraine. It seems the aura phenomenon landed in my blind spot and temporarily expanded it.

I'm going to give a bit of history and my symptoms before I go into what happened at my last GP appt in June. I was about 17 when I started to experience what I was told were migraines. Initially, it was suspected that my wisdom teeth were the source of the problem. However, do to my parents inability to communicate with me about how their dental insurance worked, I didn't get my wisdon teeth out until l was 22, which I paid for myself. I was told that once they were out my migraines would stop. Well, they didn't. Since then I've been prescribed many different migraine medications, medications that aren't for migraines, but has an affect on them, told to take supplements, a pain journal, etc. But the next visit it has been completely forgetten about and/or there isn't enough time to bring it up. In 2020, I was diagnosed with chronic migraines. I'm currently 33 (34 in two months). Would like to make note that I have technically two GPs as I was under the father care since i was three and a half and his daughter took over his practice in 2017, but he's only semi retired. The father as missed diagnosingme with ADHD and autism. My symptoms that had over the years with these migraines: -severe pain/pressure that it feels like my head is in a vice -as a kid, I described it was feeling like I'm under water. - brain fog to the pain its hard to speak/think/hold a converstion -unable to keep my eyes up too long because its too tiring to do so -passing out from the pain -nausea/vomiting (only do vomit now when its really bad) -sensitive to light/sound -mostly recently stabbing eye pain -stabbing pain in my temples -seeing auras -facial numbness/tingles The Doctor's Appointment: I have a doctors appoint early June inregards to having a migarine for two weeks straight. Nothing was helping with the pain. I tried to telling that father everything I could as he hadn't seen me in awhile and from the last visit I had with his daughter, it didn't seem that a). their records were up to date or b). they haven't been reading the records because when I spoke about some mental health struggles I was having, she said that people with bipolar... I stopped her and informed that the diagnosis had been changed by the psychiatrist in their team to ADHD (the daughter has even wrote me a script for Concerta) with autism and borderline. But what ended up happening was I talked over multiple times, informed that what I'm experiencing are not migraines, but medicine induced headaches because I will take two extra strength Tylenols and one Aleve together (daily: 2 Aleve and about 8 Tylenols) when they occur. Now, thats not the only thing I do, but that's all he allowed me to get out. I also will smoke certain strains of weed that have been proven to help with migraine pain and I find place a cool cloth at the base of neck and my forehead help as well, but I have two kids so I can only do certain things when they're not around. He ended up telling me that I can't take any pain meds for the next 3-4 months to flush everything put of my system since I've been taking too much meds, they built up, are at a toxic level and my body doesn't know how to deal with pain anymore since I take all these meds. He didn't do any blood tests or anything. He told me to get botox done and that I should apply to new doctor in my rural area to make things easier on myself. (Used to live in a meduim size city, move to a rural community 30 mins out for it) And that was pretty much the whole appointment. He gave a script with Medicine Induced Headaches on it to look up on my own time. I left there in tears as well. So, if you read this far, what can I do to get some sort help/relief. I'm not the mum I want to be with these migraines, I'm struggling with housework and I have no social life at all because of this.

Migraines. Migraines do not always include a typical headache. There are many types such as abdominal migraines/cyclical vomiting syndrome, vestibular migraines, ocular migraines, headache contralgia (migraines induced by exercise), hemiplegic migraines, etc. A migraine disorder can cause stroke especially if you're taking estrogen based birth control. Some migraines aren't even migraines but miniature strokes called trans-ischemic attacks. There is medication available for migraines. An actual headache is NOT required.

Here's some info about [sero-negative RA ](https://www.arthritis.org/diseases/more-about/what-type-of-ra-do-you-have). It actually is rare, and estimated to be at most 20% of all RA dxs. Further, it's harder to dx because the rheumatologist needs to rely on patient reported symptoms instead of easily identifiable blood work. The best way to prepare for your appointment is to keep track of your symptoms. Here's a blurb about that: Keeping track of your symptoms is helpful to you and your physicians. Documenting your pain (aching, sharp, muscle spasms, etc), when it occurs, what you do to alleviate it (rest, cold, heat, meds), and what works best. Also include things that you might not think matter (headache or migraine, energy level, mood, how you're sleeping, gender affirming hormone therapy, if AFAB then hormonal fluctuations and symptoms, or if you're dealing with peri/menopause - any of those fun things). This is going to give your physician a quick, clear picture of your daily symptoms without having to remember them. It's also helpful to show if any meds are or aren't working. Sometimes meds work quickly, but a lot of RA meds take time to build up. It's not easy to know if you're a little bit better, but looking back over time can give you a more objective view of how you're doing. Medical appointments are very short, and sometimes we have MDs that aren't great at listening; this will really help with them. There are apps for this, but I'm happy using a school planner. I keep it on my dresser, and it's now a habit. It has helped me countless times, both for me to understand my own symptom changes and to communicate them clearly to my MDs. Even if you end up with a different dx, this is the best way to prepare and advocate for yourself. I know it's exhausting and frustrating to be waiting so long for a dx, but you're on the right track! You might not get an appointment for a while: in many parts of the country specialists are hard to see these days. You might want to talk to your GP about a Prednisone taper. It will tamp down symptoms and also inform your dx. If Prednisone works, and then symptoms return it indicates inflammation; this is frequently part of the diagnostic process. I hope you get seen quickly!

One simple way to test for these problems is: if you feel as if symptoms might be indicating a migraine is coming, try taking an over the counter H1 and H2 blocker (antihistamines). Obviously, you would want to speak to a doctor of pharmacist first, but these medications are commonly available without a prescription. If you do this several times and it appears to abort the migraine, this is not necessarily proof but I maintain that it would be considered clinically significant, and worthy of further investigation.

I'm not even sure what flair to give this. I'm feeling really desperate and really need support, as I'm the only person in my circle experiencing peri- and ADD. This is really long, but if anyone can help me, I'd really appreciate it. A couple years ago, I started having all the classic peri-menopause signs: irritable, anxious, headaches, brain fog, forgetfulness, dry skin, etc. Saw my Gyno, she suggested birth control pills. Got on them, got my first ever migraine with aura, and since my family has a history of stroke, I got off that real quick. Then she suggested an IUD, but all of the horror stories I've read about them made me nope out of that option. We settled on HRT - .05 patch and 200 mg progesterone. My monthly headaches went away, but 2 weeks before my period, my moods are severely ugly. I'm mean, angry, and really unpleasant. I hate myself. Since I was already taking Effexor (for about 7 years up to that point), my family practitioner increased the dosage on that, diagnosed me with PMDD. I maxed out on the Effexor. It worked for about 2 months at that dose. At that point, she suggested I see a psychiatrist to try to figure out a better anti-depressant, anti-anxiety med. Saw the psych, he almost immediately diagnosed me with ADD, had me taper off Effexor completely, gave me a 10 mg Prozac bridge, and started me on Vyvanse 20 mg for ADD. Vyvanse worked the first couple of days I took it - I felt clear-headed, was able to accomplish so much, my head was finally "free". Day 3 or 4, it worked great until about 6 hours after I took it. I'd crash with a headache, sleepiness, and a foul mood. He suggested upping the dose to 30 mg. Tried that, same deal. Only now, when I crash, I feel like my heart is racing and get that "I can't breathe" feeling I get with anxiety. I've tried taking L-Theanine and Magnesium to head off the headache (heh), but still not feeling my best. On top of everything, I'm really down, depressed, unhappy, and just want to be myself again. I could probably try another ADD drug. I could increase the Prozac. I had my testosterone and thyroid levels checked, and they're fine. Should I even bother my gyno with a request to increase estrogen or progesterone? Is that a thing? I'm only 49, I don't want to feel like this. Yes, I exercise, drink lots of water, eat plenty of protein, and take all kinds of other supplements. I don't know what else I can do.

Hi all, if you are reading this I hope you are well. Context: I'm 28M, caucasian, european, 165cm or 5.4 feet, 75 kg, daily smoker and cannabis for 10 years, just quit recently out of the sudden after wanting to quit for a couple years now. Conditions: epidimical cyst for 10 years; migraine with aura (started 3 years ago, head CT scan clear, better with healthy food and no diary products); biopsed throat papilloma last year; cough suspect of acid reflux and of post nasal drip (nasal drip with blood 2 to 3 times per year). Overweight, sedentary, otherwise healthy. DISCLAIMER: I have health (cancer) anxiety because of losing my grandparents for cancer (breast; liver and lung) in the last 5 years and almost lost my mother to a huge meningioma and post-op complications early this year. Also anxiety for not being able to quit tobacco and cannabis. I don't expect any diagnosis from this post, this is me just letting it out from my chest and looking for possible orientation. Complaint: stomach area discomfort when sleeping on each side and on belly. Feel like a pin is being pressured in my stomach when sleeping, pain I would say 2/10, more like a pressure or discomfort. Sometimes it is a little stabbing, increasing its pain to 5/10 for a few seconds. During the day, I can feel 2 pea size lumps/nodules in the stomach area (upper left abdominal quadrant, just below the ribcage). They feel like it could be lymph nodes like the ones I feel in my neck, but I'm worried I have some underlying stomach condition. I rarely vomit, only when I have aura migraines, and more recently this vomit came with blood. My GP said it was not to worry if it is just sometimes and not regularly. I have spoken to my GP regarding a weird feeling in my chest area, just above this location in the ribcage, but I figured it was acid reflux because since I have stopped smoking and eating better, such feeling is less frequent and less intense. On the other hand, since I quit weed, my sleep is not so deep, so now I wake up during the night to change positions from one side to the other because I feel this complaint (stomach discomfort/pin being pressured in my stomach). When I was using weed, I wouldn't wake up during the night at all, but I would wake up kind of sore in the stomach in the morning, but disregarded it thinking it was just from sleeping on my belly. Now that I have discomfort/pressure while sleeping, I'm concerned if it is connected to the pea size bumps in the stomach. It sure feels so. Note: I don't have trouble swallowing, nausea, fever, I haven't lost weight, I use the bathroom just fine, I haven't lost my appetite - on contrary, I thought my appetite came from the weed but no, I eat a lot and thus feeling kind of full/bloated after eating. I will definitely tell my GP about this pea size lumps and discomfort when sleeping (he will probably just give me some medicine to sleep lol), but should I see a specialist as well? As I said, this pain doesn't leave me incapacitated and grabbing onto my belly, but is discomforting and ruining my sleep lately. If you read this far thank you for your time and if you care to help/guide on what to do it is much appreciated! TLDR: Stomach area discomfort when sleeping, feel like pin is being pressured in stomach, during the day can feel 2 pea size bumps in stomach, no real pain, just discomfort, specially when sleeping.

Hello, I am a 45 man and I have been at a loss for my symptoms that developed over 7 months ago. On the right back side of my head, one evening while out at Top Golf, I felt like something was crawling around inside of my skull for about 3 minutes. And every day since, I have had some sort of a headache. It is not a painful headache, but a headache that feels like pressure. About 3 weeks after this started, I was able to secure an appointment with a neurologist to have an MRI of the brain and nerve test. Nothing was found and the neurologist prescribed me the migraine medicine Qulipta. I refused to take it because I am not having migraines. I went to another my primary care physician, who performed a blood, urine, diabetes, kidney, and a plethora of other tests, including an additional MRI of the head and neck (with and without contrast). Again, nothing was found. He said I have a deviated septum, although I am not experiencing any of the symptoms. My breathing, congestion, etc. are fine. The doctor then felt like I was potentially developing high blood pressure so asked me to take my blood pressure whenever I was feeling the head pressure. My Blood pressure rendered normal. Through all of this, I still go to the gym, go running, walking, bowling, bike riding, function at work, etc. with no problem. So these ‚Äúheadaches‚Äù are not limiting my regular activities, just concerning. Every once in a while, I feel the pressure pinpointed on one spot of my head, and its intense for a few seconds then goes away. Other times, I feel the pressure over my whole head and feel the need to take a nap, and when I do, I wake up feeling much better. I halted all vitamin supplements I was taking and cleaned up my diet a little (I am a pescatarian). Additionally, I switched pillows and the way I sleep. Some nights are better than others. More recently, I have been waking up with light tingling on the right side of my head and neck, and I am starting to feel something off in my nasal cavity. Now I am even more lost at my symptoms as it feels like they are progressing. I am starting to think this could be Occipital Neuralgia (ON). Has anyone experiences anything similar? What has been your treatment and outcome?

I feel like people who get constant migraines are the ones who know how and it is. I really feel for you, even though I don‚Äôt know you. It‚Äôs like the first thing I used to think about when I wake up is if I had a migraine that day and if I was bed ridden. I take two 200mg magnesium pills per night. I believe the recommended is like 350mg, but ya know. I‚Äôm lazy to cut pills, and I haven‚Äôt had an issue. I also had a huge hormonal imbalance that it helped with. I had the implanon and IUD before, and I used to have brown-ish periods from the progesterone. When I took the magnesium, it turned the period back to normal. If it wasn‚Äôt red, I‚Äôd take a little extra the night before. Not sure if you‚Äôve heard of a book called the period manual, but there are ways to regulate your period that isn‚Äôt birth control, and it‚Äôs the way that women can figure out what might be wrong with their bodies. Doctors generally prescribe birth control because it‚Äôs the ‚Äúcure all‚Äù to so many things, but my depression was causing me to spiral‚Äîit made my depression a lot worse. With food, I eliminated almost everything first. Only started eating rice for two days. Then added broccoli. Then chicken. Little to no seasonings. Every little thing matters.

My mom bought me the loop quiet to try because she said it works for both her and my sister (also migraine suffers). I tried it. I don't know if I'm putting them in wrong or what. I don't like them at all. I tried each of the sizes, and I don't know what is more comfortable. The tightest seal was the largest one but I didn't like how tight the seal was. I have very bad allergies and every sniffle/sneeze I felt some discomfort in my ears while wearing the loops. The smaller ends did not make a tight seal so it was uncomfortable/pointless. I was also creeped out by the sounds of my neck joints. The loops did a great job blocking out external sounds but it really amplified/isolated the internal sounds. Every time.i moved my neck around I could hear all of the crepitus. That was distracting to me, especially now. All I can think of is this crepitus that I didn't notice before wearing those loops. I don't like them and I probably won't wear them again. I feel bad because they were a gift.

Hello all, I would just like to share my personal experience and migraine discovery over the past year in case anyone could benefit. I‚Äôm a 26 F and was on birth control since I was 16 until last October. Since HS (realized the same time I started BC) I would get 1-2 migraines a month. I got an MRI and have tried so many medications. My OBGYN once recommended I try skipping my period every month because maybe the dip in my hormones was causing the migraines. I eventually accepted the fact I would have migraines forever and was a regular at my local urgent care for tordol and steroid shots. Hoping this can help at least one person

Huh. Okay. On second thought. You shouldn‚Äôt start on a preventative when you don‚Äôt even know if you have migraines. You should rather start with an abortive medication. That you take for an individual attack rather than every thay. That way you can test the migraine hypothesis much quicker, without waiting months to slowly get to the right dosage and endure side effects. Abortives you could ask for are triptans and Nurtec. They work immediately. While topiramate will take weeks and months.

33F. I am beginning my journey of diagnosing (or ruling out) MS after experiencing symptoms that have worsened over the past 15+ years. After years of medical gaslighting - "it's just anxiety, it's just hormones", I'm finally feeling ready to take the plunge and meet with a neurologist and get a proper MRI. But knowing that I may also have to get a lumbar puncture (which is going to put me in some medical debt along with the MRI) to potentially get an accurate diagnosis has led me to start gaslighting myself. It's a big reason why I've been putting off seeing a specialist or pushing for more testing. I experience my symptoms and play them off as something else, "maybe I'm just dehydrated", "maybe it's just because it's allergy season", "maybe it IS just anxiety", and a million other reasons I try to talk myself out of spending the money on an MRI because of my fear I'll go into debt for nothing. But then there is the part of me, that when my symptoms worsen, I feel like it isn't all in my head that MS is possible. It feels so so likely. My first symptoms began at 16/17. I was experiencing severe fatigue, easily tired, and heat intolerance which led to headache and shortness of breath. I'd have periods where I'd get dizzy and disoriented, and 2 episodes of fainting within a month but was told it was just anxiety (I was also dx with neurocardiogenic syncope). I believe my next episode was likely in 2014/2015. I started experiencing some GI issues that seemed unprovoked, and suddenly I was experiencing frequent urination, urge to urinate immediately after emptying the bladder, and decreased libido. I was dx with overactive bladder and told the GI issues and low libido were just anxiety. Also during this time I started having frequent migraines and my vision just felt "off" at times, especially in hot environments. I experienced tingling in my fingers and toes for the first time, especially in extreme temperatures. 2016 - experienced my first ocular migraine. I only experience them 1-2 times every 4-5 months thankfully. During this time I was also noticing that my fatigue was continuing to worsen, especially in the heat. 2019 to present - all my prior symptoms seemed to ebb and flow. Sometimes they were bad and other times they were barely noticable. I'd go through periods of urinary frequency that made working and sleeping difficult, and within a week or two feel like I was back to baseline (still having some nocturia). I got kidney stones twice. My symptoms definitely appeared to worsen significantly in the heat - I feel pressure behind my eyes that makes my vision a little blurry temporarily, the fatigue is through the roof, I struggle to focus and get quickly irritable, muscle soreness, headache and shortness of breath. When I cool down the symptoms appear to resolve. The shortness of breath has started becoming a lot more frequent and there are times when I've needed to use a cane due to fatigue and dizziness. I'm feeling numbness in my left foot inconsistently (sometimes also the right but rarely), mild temor and weakness in right hand (very rarely in left), and my left knee becomes very stiff (painful when bending or going down stairs). Sharp burning pain in a very specific spot on my middle right back that comes and goes. Tinnitus is nearly constant since the past 7 months. Forgetfulness episodes are happening more often, forgetting words for things or whole phrases, which results in me feeling flustered. All of these symptoms seem to come in cycles, not always together, each cycle almost always seems to being a different combination of symptoms. I have so much more I want to say but I've already written a novel. If you've gotten this far, bless you. I guess I'm just wondering if I'm wasting my time and money seeking a MS diagnosis. But I'm exhausted of feeling this way. I want to go to the beach and not feel like I have the flu. I want to sleep through the night or make it through a work day without having to pee multiple times. I'd like to be able to go to the gym and exercise with friends without nearly passing out after some light exercise. I guess I just want an answer that confirms this isn't in my head. That after years of being told it's "just anxiety" or "just hormones", I was right that something else was causing this decreased quality of life. But here I am again gaslighting myself.

This is interesting. So I hadn‚Äôt drank any alcohol in like a year. I went to a fair and I was feeling great and thought, I‚Äôll have one beer. And wouldn‚Äôt you know it. An hour later and here comes the migraine. I took three aspirin 325mg/each. Did absolutely nothing. In my pained anxiety I decided to do a search and discover that beer actually causes an insane amount of histamine to flood the body. Histamine is what is released when our body senses an allergy that doesn‚Äôt agree with it. I had the idea to take benedryl and sure enough I was fine the next morning. Perhaps I should switch to benedryl when I feel a migraine coming on.

My tale of woe: I saw a neurologist who diagnosed it. When I was a kid, I'd take the correct dose for my age. That seemed to not work so well, so I started taking more. I was up to 8 OTC strength ibuprofen with little effect on the headaches. When Excedrin became a thing, I never took too much like that. But the headache never quite went away. So I'd take the correct dose. For years, I was basically *giving* myself headaches. I had to do a migraine diet for 3 months (no citrus, no caffeine, no chocolate, no MSG, no cheese..). Then he said yep, it's Rebound. Put me on a daily anti-seizure med that can help with migraines, and once I did that for a while, I got switched to an as-needed med. I wouldn't worry unless you did something similar... (Fun fact: my neurologist split one year, I eventually found out he went to Riyadh, of all places. From the US.)

Have you actually tried every med or just every class of meds? Like even within the CGRP meds there are quite a few, and I read a study that they should be trialed for at least 6 months to determine efficacy. There are also lots of meds that aren't specifically for migraine, but could help with prevention or can be used off label to help with specific symptoms. For example, I take singulair, zyrtec, claritin, and sudafed daily to prevent sinus related migraine. What accommodations can you add for yourself to avoid triggers? Warm lighting, sunglasses, earplugs, living like a vampire. Accommodating my sensory needs helped me get out of central sensitization, I'm not sure how well my meds would have worked if I wasn't able to avoid most of my triggers at that time.

These honestly sound like migraine headaches especially given how focal (in one spot) they are. Worth seeing your doctor about them, because there are medications that can help stop migraines when they get started, or even to reduce them happening in the first place. Keeping track of them using an app (Migraine Buddy is one I've seen recommended by neurologists) is also very helpful to see if you can figure out what some triggers may be.

Capsaicin is a herbal pain reliever. I take it as a herbal abortive along with curcumin and ginger. Very effective trio. You could probably just take a capsule! Might be better for teeth and tummy. I do want to mention medication adaptation headaches though since you disclosed your Tylenol use. If Tylenol alone was the only drug you were taking, if you took it more than 14 days a month (dose per day is mostly irrelevant) than you could‚Äôve contracted MAH, a secondary migraine disorder that makes your primary disorder more severe and chronic. Cutting down will give some relief but won‚Äôt treat the MAH. Once I treated my MAH, now I have ~5 migraines a month, down from 20-30

I'm a 39/m with a Intermittent Exotropia aka lazy. I started getting regular migraines in my mid to late 20s. I'd say I usually catch my migraines with meds before they start coming on but I usually take medication every other day.

My mom has suffered from migraines her whole life. In recent years they have increased in frequency with her experiencing an onset of symptoms (aura) every 1-2 weeks, with full migraines breaking through (i.e. rescue meds do not work) every 3-6 months. For her, the aura typically presents in the form of dizziness, difficulty speaking and visual blind spots. In the case her rescue medicine (Zavzpret nasal spray) does not work, a break-through migraine takes the form of severe head pain, confusion, sensitivity to light, aphasia and sometimes hallucinations that last about 24-72 hours where she is confined to bed. These episodes typically end with a trip to the ER on day 3 or 4 and needing a migraine cocktail. She takes Qulipta daily as her preventative and had been for about two years. Earlier this year she started seeing a new neurologist that recommended botox treatments. Her first injections took place in early May. On June 22nd she had a migraine break through. This one lasted 4-5 days and ended in the ER as usual. After this migraine on July 1st, her neurologist increased her Qulipta dose from 30mg to 60mg. Still experiencing weakness and shakiness, my mom decided to start a steroid on July 3rd (Which has helped in the past). Halfway through the steroid dose and about 10 days into the higher Qulipta dosage, she experienced a second migraine break through on July 10th. We cannot recall a time that she's ever had two migraines within such a short span of time. Today on July 27th, 17 days later, she has still not fully recovered from this migraine. Her aphasia symptoms have been improving in small increments each day, but have never persisted this long ever before. She still feels shaky and weak. Her 2nd set of botox injections are set for next week on August 2nd. We are on the fence as to whether to stick these out or not. We are worried the botox could be the reason for the increase in migraine frequency and worsening of symptoms, but we really have no idea. Her neurologist says that the botox is not the cause and that we should continue. Does anyone have any experience with botox injections - good or bad? Any advice is appreciated and all stories are welcome!

Sorry about this wall of text. I've actually tried all of the CGRP meds, except the infusion one because that one can't be taken with Emgality (the one I'm on currently) and my neuro was concerned that if the infusion failed, I'd be in hell for 3 months while it left my system. I was lucky to get put on Aimovig almost immediately when it came out. But after a few years it was like my body got used to it. I was moved to Ajovy which I had a weird total body allergic reaction to. So now it's Emgality. I'm also asthmatic and allergic to way too much stuff, so I'm on quite a lot of allergy meds and some overlapping (with migraine) asthma meds. I'm on a blood pressure medicine specifically for my migraines. My second one because the first caused heart problems. I'm on zonisamide for migraines (off label use) and emgality. I have ubrelvy for abortive. I've tried the rest of the abortives, some did nothing, some bad such awful side effects (and such little migraine improvement) it wasn't really worth taking them. I've tried Topiramate. One made me so unable to think I bearly crashed my car twice in the weeks starting it and the other was tanking my kidneys. I‚Äôm sorry to hear this. Have you tried any of the newer migraine medications? Qulipta, ubrelvy, Zavspret, they‚Äôre CGRP antagonists. That has to do with inflammation. Ajovy and Emgality are also similar. I would also consider going to the therapist and maybe a psychiatrist to see if any psych meds might at least help your mood and help you cope better.

Ask your doctor for CGRP-inhibitors. Injections (usually every 28 days) as a preventative option and gepants (oral: Nurtec and Ubrelvy, nasal spray: Zavzpret) as an abortive option. As for scans: there isn't really a "migraine-scan". You've already got an MRI and if it came back all clear, it's improbable another scan would bring you closer to a definite result. We're not able to find THE cause of migraines for now and I wouldn't spend my valuable resources on that but instead on finding a preventative treatment that works well. There's research being done and we've got CGRP-inhibitors out of it and a couple of other avenues are being studied right now. All we can do as patients is to get the best treatment and, if we're lucky, participate in drug trials to find new meds or research trials to find a cause.

Hello and welcome to our Sub! I think the most important thing you can do to prepare for any medical appt is to track your symptoms. Here's a blurb about it: Keeping track of your symptoms is helpful to you and your physicians. Documenting your pain (aching, sharp, muscle spasms, etc), when it occurs, what you do to alleviate it (rest, cold, heat, meds), and what works best. Also include things that you might not think matter (headache or migraine, energy level, mood, how you're sleeping, gender affirming hormone therapy, if AFAB then hormonal fluctuations and symptoms, or if you're dealing with peri/menopause - any of those fun things). This is going to give your physician a quick, clear picture of your daily symptoms without having to remember them. It's also helpful to show if any meds are or aren't working. Sometimes meds work quickly, but a lot of RA meds take time to build up. It's not easy to know if you're a little bit better, but looking back over time can give you a more objective view of how you're doing. Medical appointments are very short, and sometimes we have MDs that aren't great at listening; this will really help with them. There are apps for this, but I'm happy using a school planner. I keep it on my dresser, and it's now a habit. It has helped me countless times, both for me to understand my own symptom changes and to communicate them clearly to my MDs. I also have RA (and OA) in my TMJs. Talk to your dentist about a night guard! Also get a face ice pack wrap (just search on Google or Amazon) and, if you don't already have one, a good blender. Sometimes all you can do is just rest your jaw, and smoothies (or frappes!) help immensely üòÅ

Nortriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant that is commonly prescribed as a preventive medication for migraines and certain chronic pain conditions. Regarding its potential effects on palinopsia (persisting visual trails/afterimages) in those with visual snow syndrome (VSS) Some tips that may help: Start at a low dose and increase slowly Give it adequate time as symptoms may stabilize Have a plan to stop the medication if palinopsia becomes intolerable Ensure you are getting quality sleep as fatigue can exacerbate palinopsia Overall, while there are anecdotal concerns, nortriptyline may be worth a try under medical supervision for its migraine prevention benefits, especially if you can stop it without issues if palinopsia worsens significantly. Being informed of the potential risk is helpful.

You might also find this interesting. Adhd people don't tend to form natural habits of patterns or routines. We have to think about it and each step every time. For example... nurotypical people? Like my husband. He has a morning routine. Gets up. Gets his coffee. Showers. Brushes his teeth. Kisses me goodbye. Feeds the cats. Grabs his keys, phone, wallet, bag, and then calls down the hall to say he loves me and locks the door before being off for his day. He naturally does all of this without a single thought about it. I wake up? I have to remember coffee exists. Question breakfast. Remember to brush my teeth, My hair, the steps of my make up. While I do the same things everyday too... I will forget parts of it or have to set things a certain way to naturally not forget them. Like my pills by the light switch to remember to take them. I have no set time because every day is a mystery of my brain function of remember to do the same steps I've done everyday for years. There is no "I just do it. I don't think about it." For adhd people. We have to make conscious effort to do anything. ...And if I miss a step of something new? Like I forgot to take my migraine prevention pills? I will literally forget they exist. I took them six months straight without fail. One day put them in the wrong pocket of my bag. Then when my refill date came and they gave me a new bottle I have a sudden light bulb light up that I'd forgot about them. Adhd people do this with nearly anything. Go to the gym? Skip a day... suddenly something will remind you and realize you haven't gone in three months.

Great video, harrowing. There were a few vignettes, but the first one's TL;DR: 36yo F with history of migraine presents to ED with severe headache, initially without focal deficits or aphasia. Gets noncontrast CT head read as no acute intracranial abnormality. In retrospect there was a falcine hyperdensity concerning for venous sinus thrombosis. Patient returns to ED the next day with worsening headache, seems to have been delayed in triage, waits several hours in ED then develops aphasia, repeat CT head shows L temporal intracerebral hemorrhage requiring decompressive hemicraniectomy, poor outcome, later progressed to death. Video includes subpoena with radiologist who apologizes and says "I missed it. Hundred percent I missed it. And it was my job to see it. It's caused me tremendous pain. I lost a lot of sleep over it." Radiologist committed suicide the day after the deposition. Patient's family later admits the suit didn't help anything.

Welcome to the Quest! I‚Äôm so sorry that you‚Äôre experiencing so many migraines. You very well could be in autistic burnout. Feel free to DM me!
