Thought I'd write this as I think a lot of people would relate to this. I get very frustrated at people that call migraine "a bad headache". I've mentioned that I have it to colleagues and the response is normally "Oh I get those too - normally I take tylenol or excedrin then go to work and I'm fine". My response is "I cant do that. With mine my vision is slurred and everything that emits light will streak, I get agitated and struggle with memory, I get vertigo and dizzy with nausea, it feels like someone is stabbing a saw into my head and every sound and light makes it grind harder. When I have a migraine I'm prone to falling, cannot drive, and struggle to walk". And many people are suprised when I say this and sometimes ask me if it's really migraine or another neurological issue. Migraine can happen with or without pain. Migraine may or may not distort vision. Migraine isnt a headache, it is a brain "oopsie" that can lead to incredibly variable symptoms and results. Even some doctors think migraine must involve a headache and a severe one at that. I know that every chronic illness has its own level of misunderstanding from the general public. But I do very much long for the day when people dont self-diagnose their bad headache as a migraine. A time in which the generalized "bad headache" description is changed or expanded.

Not really. There‚Äôs basically no risk with the plaster. I mean, an extremely small risk (much smaller than with pills) but so small as to not matter at all except if you have a diagnosed clotting disorder. Here are bad things about estrogen in pills that transdermal estrogen doesn‚Äôt have: pills have: 1. ‚Å†‚Å†increased risk of blood clots (very small risk for those who are younger so this isn‚Äôt a huge concern) 2. ‚Å†‚Å†increased risk of stroke (again, risk very small so don‚Äôt worry about this one too much if young unless you have preexisting issues like existing clotting or stroke risks or history) 3. ‚Å†‚Å†increased risk of gall bladder problems 4. ‚Å†‚Å†increased risk of cardiovascular negatives 5. ‚Å†‚Å†increased risk of migraines IF you‚Äôre susceptible to them, due to oral estrogen dumping all the E into your system at once, while patches give you a steady dose 24/7 6. ‚Å†Contraindicated if you have migraine with aura due to stroke risk. Transdermal is OK though. 7. ‚Å†mostly a different kind of estrogen if you care about that kind of thing. Patches are estradiol, the main ovarian estrogen, the main estrogen your body has before menopause. It‚Äôs more powerful than most other types. Birth control pills are ethinyl estradiol, which has a long half-life (estradiol has a short half-life). Hormone replacement has various different kinds of estrogen but a lot of it is converted into estrone in the liver. Estrone is the main post-menopausal estrogen released by body fat. It‚Äôs a weaker estrogen than estradiol. None of this may matter if you don‚Äôt care about it. Some people are very particular about it as it feels different and has different side effects. 8. ‚Å†‚Å†risk of lowering availability of thyroid hormones if you already have thyroid issues 9. ‚Å†‚Å†will lower your available testosterone, which can affect libido

Not looking for a sleep aid so I don't need all the *other* ingredients I keep finding blended with it, though given Chamomile's own relaxing properties finding what I'm looking for is still easier said than done. What I'm looking for is a pocket friendly, "wandering around at my retail job" friendly way to use chamomile for its properties in both migraine treatment and heartburn relief. Preferably in a "take as needed" form rather than something I take once a day and hope it staves off the symptoms for the next 24 hours. Reason I'm interested in a gummy in particular is because I have a hyperactive gag reflex. I can usually swallow pills without trouble as long as I've got something to drink, but I've never been able to dry swallow and sometimes even *with* a drink any size pill will feel like I'm choking it down rather than swallowing it. (And trying not to vomit it back up before I've finally swallowed it.) Not too keen on the lozenge idea because keeping something in my mouth until it's dissolved can also trigger the reflex (I can't chew gum any more for this same reason, while at least a gummy is only in my mouth until I've chewed it down to size), but the act of sucking on one, I believe due to saliva production, does seem to help with heartburn as well. I've looked at tinctures as an option but I'd need to consider the alcohol free variations... can't stand the taste of alcohol so even if there isn't much in it that won't be very good for my gag reflex either unless it's totally undetectable. I'm currently trying Iberogast which is... not cheap. Not the most expensive thing out there but if it does end up being helpful I'll be hoping that their "proprietary blend" becomes available in a store brand *soon*. But I also question its effectiveness for heartburn for the simple fact that one of its ingredients is peppermint... which I like the scent of for my migraines but which can make heartburn worse due to it relaxing the wrong things....

There are clinical and diagnosable conditions named headache. For example, cluster headaches. For another example medication overuse headache. Tension-type headache. Hypnic headache. Thunderclap headache. There are dozens of clinically differentiated headache types. All are different, and none of which are migraines. There is medical literature to back this up. Do you have any to back up your claim that all headaches are migraines? A 'doctor' wouldn't classify all headaches as a varying degree of migraine because it isn't even fully understood what causes migraines in the first place. However, we know what causes the head pain in a lumbar puncture headache - also a clinically differentiated form of headache. You can treat it with straight caffeine, which is usually a no-no with an actual migraine.

Sort of. I‚Äôve also had allergy/sinus issues for years, but my initial visits were about the more classic VM symptoms (dizziness, nausea, etc). However, I notice a DRAMATIC increase in VM symptoms when my allergies and sinuses are flaring up. This past month I‚Äôve had awful, frequent VM attacks, and one that sent me to the ER. At the ER they measured my temperature and I was running a fever which should have been the first clue something else was up. I eventually found out through my trusted ENT that I‚Äôve had a Staph infection in my sinuses for over a month and it wasn‚Äôt just allergies bothering me. After getting my sinuses cultured and an antibiotic specific to the bacteria, I‚Äôm feeling so much better. All that to say that in my experience, sinus issues are a huge trigger for vm. I know it‚Äôs certainly possible for the migraine to cause some sinus or allergy type symptoms but for me the sinus problems always precede the migraine.

I just was diagnosed a year or so ago. It made sense. I have had unusual symptoms all my life. I figure I have been having symptoms all my life I did not know what was going on. I was always tired and never felt like I had a good night's sleep, so I was labeled lazy. My mom used to make a big deal of it so when you talk about shame I can fill volumes on that subject. I felt all I could do was to try my hardest to do what everybody told me too my complaints were blunted by comments of laziness, and no one ever said they were sorry for misjudging me people do not like to be wrong. I started having severe migraines at age 14, I still have them but I have learned to deal with it. I was very anemic at birth which is still the case although I take iron supplements. I always had stomach aches and stuff like that and crushing headaches migraine and tension. So now everything makes sense it is refreshing to hear that even though it's an unpleasant fact. Knowledge is key. Looking back I feel I had this condition at birth if that possible. What kid sleeps instead of going swimming? Or take a nap when camping? I am relieved to finally get the right answer if anyone out there reading this had a similar to mine, I would be interested to hear your story. to

Quick background, i'm 36M, had TBI when I was 8 years old. I can't go out without atlius tinted contact lenses, tinted glasses, clip-on sunglasses, and a hat, whether it's day or night. Botox seems to be the only thing that works for me, but after 3 years, it only works for about a month and a half. The other month and a half, I'm on average 2 or 3 out of 10, i can go a week without leaving the house, I can't even go to my mailbox. I've tried numerous products that might help, and I'd say about 95% of them were failures. My wife told me about a product she saw on Instagram called ZOK Instant Migraine Relief. I was hesitant to try it because most of these are posted to get a free product and they sure don't post the negative ones. However, I decided to give it a try. I experienced great relief when I applied negative pressure to my left ear. It made me wonder if it could be related to vertigo, as neurologists never mentioned it. So, I looked into the vertigo Epley maneuver, which involves at home movements that provide relief from vertigo symptoms. When I tried it, i went from being miserable 2/10 to 8/10 in just 4 minutes, and I had a fantastic day, which is not something I'm accustomed to. Diclofenac (and other pain killers and triptans) shouldn't be taken more than 3 consecutive days or 10 days per a rolling 30 day period to avoid MOH (medication overuse headache) and damage to your internal organs, especially liver, kidney and your gastrointestinal tract. You need to see a specialist and discuss preventative treatment options (CGRP-inhibitors, botox, propranolol/metoprolol, amitriptyline, topiramate etc.) to reduce frequency and severity of your migraines and abortive treatment options (gepants, triptans, ditan) to adequately treat your migraine when they occur. Usually a neurologist specialising in headaches is the best option but if you're unable to schedule an appointment, see a regular neurologist. Have you ever been on any preventative treatment?

The cure for that is to never get married. (j/k) I've had all types of headaches in my life, including a wife and two children. (OK, I'll be serious now) The medical term for headache is migraine. Some people think there is a difference, but typically people misuse the term "headache" to refer to a wide variety of migraines. And the problem is that an "annoying" migraine can be the warning shot. Having that "annoying" headache can tell you that you're going to be projectile vomiting / dry heaves soon. It was terrible timing that when I was suffering my worst migraines was when I had two children below the age of 3. During some of my migraine attacks, it would have been physically impossible for me to do anything at all to care for either of my children. When you are bent over the porcelain throne with uncontrollable dry heaves for 15 minutes (making it nearly impossible to breathe, by the way), it's not going to matter much if baby is screaming at the top of her lungs. But before a migraine gets nearly that bad, I would often have what I would describe as an "annoying" headache. It was annoying for two reasons. One, while it didn't stop me from doing anything, it did make me want to do nothing at all. Second, when I felt this way, I knew I was in for a very VERY bad day. Anyway, when I had what would be described as an "annoying" headache, it would have been very irresponsible for my wife to take off and leave kiddos to my care alone. Because for me, that was the warning that I would be totally incapacitated soon. It would have been dangerous for the babies to leave them in my care for the simple reason that I knew I (soon) wouldn't even be able to care for myself. It took doctors a while to get my migraines under control. Over the years I took various prescription meds including antidepressants and (beta blockers?, from memory). And I eventually grew out of my migraine phase to the point where I was neither taking migraine prevention medicine NOR was I suffering from migraines. I know it's fashionable to beat up men for being lazy fathers. I get it. But depending on how severe a migraine is, it could entirely justify leaving kiddo to be cared for by the parent who is not suffering from migraines. For the safety of the child.

Hi! My neuro was happy to have me try Frova, but unfortunately, it didn't help my pain at all, so it wasn't a great option for me. It literally didn't even touch my pain - it was so weird. But, I know everyone reacts differently to all the triptans, so I think it's definitely worth trying. I've basically just stuck with triptans, Excedrin Migraine (which always works for me in a pinch on days when I've already taken my allotted triptans for the week), and also the migraine supplements (CoQ10, Magnesium, Riboflavin). The supplements have helped to reduce the number of migraine attacks I get each month, which has been great because whenever I've tried more natural remedies for anything, they have never worked for me üòÇ But these did. I started to notice my migraines getting better after about 3-4 months of consistently taking the supplements. I still get them frequently during my period, but instead of 9-12 each month during my cycle, I get 6-10-ish. I've also noticed I get fewer severe attacks, and more mild migraines. It's a small win, but I'll take it! I hope the Frova works for you. Reviews online that I read sounded so wonderful, and it's such a great option for many women with menstrual migraines.

I'm so sorry you had to go through this. Sounds so frustrating and familiar. Ugh. I'm also very sensitive to smell, before a migraine. WITH a 10/10 migraine, that's actual torture so I totally get you. Migraines have taught me how deeply important it is to self advocate because of how invisible they are. Suffering in immense pain no one else understands is debilitating in itself, especially when you're at the hospital and they're running around like chickens with their heads cut off. In my experience, they honestly don't know how to treat a 10/10 migraine. I've been to ER maybe 4-5 times for a 10/10 or red migraine as my neurologist calls it, and their treatment changes every time. I've been given migraine cocktails a few times, and the more recent times it's just sumatriptan which I already have a prescription for. In Ontario, they go by the "migraine guidelines" which changed recently. Honestly they're useless with migraines. I've learned their routine with ER screening and now get ahead of them, telling them all the tests, doctors, medications I'm on just to not waste my/their time. Believe it or not, the last two times the doctor actually said "so what do you want to do?" !!?? LIKE WHAT DO YOU MEAN???? You're the doctors! I need pain relief now!!!! Omg. These days I stay home because I couldn't bother, the fluorescent lights, annoying people, lack of knowledge and help all to be sent home with the same migraine. I think it's a very shared experience we all have where the ER makes us feel gaslit, doesn't help, sends us home and we're left in the same if not worse place then before. I hope you have access to a neurologist who specializes in migraines, it's truly changed my life with them. It's a process but so worth it. With the lack of research on migraines, at least a neurologist has access to the best medication and knowledge so you can try and get a good handle on future pain management through medication and different routines. We believe you and are here for you! I'm so glad I found this community, it makes me feel less alone.

The weather here lately has been causing absolute havoc for a lot of people's heads, and I wanted to share how we found some relief. Fyi I'm not a doctor, but we just solved this for my girlfriend. At least as far as treating the symptoms. This is not medical advice, talk to your doctor if needed and do your own research about drug interactions etc. She suffers these migraines as a result of the pressure changes and subsequent swelling of nasal passageways/valves in her sinuses. The past several weeks here in Toronto have been hell on earth for her. She described to me how her symptoms feel and I realized how similar it was to my chronic sinus infections. How I could get relief with a specific nasal spray. Here in Canada the brand I found is Drixoral Nasal Congestion. The key ingredient is oxymetazoline, it shrinks the blood vessels and tissue in the sinuses and lets your head and sinus finally feel a sense of pressure relief. In the USA the same stuff is Vicks Sinex, again look for the oxymetazoline ingredient. Some nasal sprays contain other pain medicine like acetaminophen, so watch out for doubling up on that if you already take other pain killers. This is over the counter stuff, easy to get from most stores. Please read the dosing instructions carefully, you can't use this stuff for more than 3 days at a time, and it has dosage limits even inside of 12 and 24 hours. Its powerful stuff. If you do a little googling you'll find that it's most effective if you use it when you wake up with a migraine, as it will help stop the symptoms and swelling before it really gets cooking. That said, my girlfriend used it last night for the first time and woke up without a migraine for the first time in a while, so it might still work for you regardless. Again, this is not medical advice. I'm just trying to give a psa for people who might need help. This is a product marketed for sinus problems and decongestion, not necessarily migraines. But, if you get air pressure related headaches that radiate from behind the eyes and sinuses, I really hope this can help you find relief. Although this can only be used for very short dosages and periods of time, I think it can help break the cycle of swelling and help keep you from being in an endless cycle of migraines. p.s. I tried to post about this in r/Toronto because I've seen so many people commiserating about their migraines there, but one of the mods argued with me that it's not about Toronto and threatened to ban me. So here I am. I hope this post helps some people.

Hello! It‚Äôs been ten years that I‚Äôve been dealing with migraines and honestly I think I‚Äôve came a long way to handle it. Howeveeeeeer, I dislike the visual aura that I always get. Starts with flashy spots, difficulties to focus and an odd visual feel. Progresses towards losing my whole peripheral vision and more spread out ‚Äúwebs‚Äù of flashy and sparkly areas, essentially partially blind. I just get bored that I have to endure to visual altercations for an hour or so. Also to have to take that in consideration for everything since it happens so often (like once a week in average). I‚Äôve recently began to wonder if there‚Äôs any trick and any ‚Äúworks for me‚Äù sort of thing that I could try on, to speed it up and cool it down. The way that I‚Äôve learned how to deal with the migraine makes me consider that there‚Äôs still a bunch to learn. Like back in the day I wouldn‚Äôt be able to read at all and nowadays I kinda still can despite everything else staying almost the same. PS: I guess I should state that most often my migraine pain isn‚Äôt super high and I have a pretty good pain resistance, I almost never take pain killers. This is probably the reason why I personally find it easy to manage my migraine.

I was just told to keep my stress under complete control if possible, since it can cause migraine. She said that some people she has seen in the past have had their migraine symptoms so bad that they start causing a cycle of: worrying about a migraine so much > this causes high stress levels > the stress levels are elevated so high you get another migraine > then you are even MORE stressed out and worried to get even another migraine > you enter a cycle of nearly constant migraine. Not to scare you or anything lol. But hope this helps highlight the importance of stress management for people with migraine that is frequently occurring. Hi everyone, We are a group of tech enthusiasts who are all too familiar with the struggles of living with migraines, as many of us experience them ourselves. We're working on a project to explore new ways to manage migraines more effectively and improve the quality of life for those affected by this condition. To create something truly helpful, we need to understand the diverse experiences and challenges faced by others in the migraine community. That's where you come in! We‚Äôve put together a short survey to gather insights that will guide our efforts. [https://forms.gle/KeFHDUwSNAxUE9HE7](https://forms.gle/KeFHDUwSNAxUE9HE7) Your participation is completely voluntary, and every question is optional, so you can share as much or as little as you feel comfortable with. Your feedback will be invaluable in helping us develop solutions that can make a real difference. Thank you so much for your time and input. Together, we can work towards better migraine management and a better quality of life for all of us. Wishing you all many pain-free days ahead!

Hi all. About a year ago, I started having heart palpitations. I went through the entire heart monitor routine for 2 weeks. Came back clean. I got into meal prepping and running, and my gerd/reflux symptoms are pretty much nonexistent if I stick to that. But if I start skipping workouts, or eating some spicy things, I‚Äôm back at it. My concern though, is these tension headaches. I get them pretty regularly, and it seems to be unaffected by diet. Tried going without caffeine for a week and no change. Today, I woke up with a headache and some reflux symptoms. Took some Pepcid, drank a lot of water, headache was unchanged but the reflux seemed to calm down. Then, I started feeling slightly sore in the throat. Then, the lingering headache changed to an intense almost migraine pain for about 5 seconds. Heart rate shot up to 145. Then it went back down to resting 65ish. Has anyone else had these before? At first, I thought they were anxiety induced because I was going through a lot of stressful events around the first one. They used to be pretty severe (ended up going to the ER for two of them after my heart rate kept staying around 130-170 for 10 minutes) but they‚Äôve slowly tapered down. I have an endoscopy scheduled but I can‚Äôt get in until late September.

If you mean you are trying to claim the sinus headaches as headaches separately, that is pyramiding. If you are saying you have migraines or headaches that are not sinus headaches that have been diagnosed and the symptoms can be differentiated, then yes you can claim that. Example, a "migraine" that affects the back of the head may be distinctly separate from "sinus headaches" that occur in the frontal sinus area.

There is merit to the idea imho especially with migraines being highly comorbid. I take a few supplements for that and migraine and do cold water, seems to help me but I'm not making general health claims.

I'm sorry you're dealing with this, I do understand how debilitating a daily headache can be. Whenever I see a post about this particular problem, I share my experience in case it might possibly help someone else. Years ago I was formally diagnosed with Chronic Daily Headache. This was in addition to frequent migraines. The daily headache was not a migraine, but it was painful and added a lot of stress to my life. The medication that completely eliminated the daily headache for me was mirtazapine. I took it for apprx. three years, and after I stopped, the daily headaches never came back. It didn't really help with migraines, though. I use separate meds for those. I will note that this med would cause me to strongly crave sweets and carbs after I took my dose at night, and that was hard to resist. I did put on a few pounds. But over time, with effort, I trained myself to ignore that urge as much as possible, and I maintained my weight from there. For me, the relief from the daily headache was worth the cravings that came with it. It was a side effect I was willing to learn to live with as the daily headaches were just brutal to keep enduring. I hope you can find something that helps!

I've had migraines since around 16 - I'm 36 now and they've gotten worse in the last 10 years. I usually get one right before my period, but sometimes they can come randomly. If I can catch it in time, my triptan medication helps. But if I develop a migraine in the night and wake up with it, I'm too late and have to suffer. I don't have nausea with my migraines BUT I puke a lot. It's the strangest thing because I have to remain perfectly still because the vomiting is triggered when I move. Like if I switch sides in bed, I'll start getting a hot flash and then the puking happens. I can't even keep sips of water down. The puking is so violent it hurts my stomach muscles ... Just constant wretching. My migraine pain is behind my right eyeball socket and I found a face compression hat that you keep in the fridge and it helps but basically we all know that during a migraine attack, the key is just to take it one minute at a time and try to survive. They suck and I wish these were more understood.

Hey OP, I know this post is old, but I wanted to reach out and ask you how you are doing and if you figured out any more about your VM vs autistic burnout question? I have been dealing with VM on a daily basis since early January this year. This is the third period in my life dealing with daily fluctuating VM symptoms. I have had this previously, but it did manage to deal and it became more like episodic migraine for long periods. I don‚Äôt really get headaches, but I get all the usual light & sound sensitivity, dizziness, pattern sensitivity, screen & busy environment sensitivity, fatigue, realisation, and major brain fog. I have recently realised that I may be autistic. I am a 41 year old woman and probably highly masked. My experience with migraine this year has helped me realise that I have huge sensory issues that I‚Äôve been ignoring my whole life, I‚Äôm still unraveling it all. I have identified as a highly sensitive person for the last decade, only to realise lately that the general thought on HSP these days is that it is simply autism. Tonight I was reading a bit about autistic burnout, and it hit me like a brick that the symptoms sound so incredibly similar to vestibular migraine. Like crazy similar. I feel like I‚Äôm making a huge breakthrough in understanding myself. Do I have a constant migraine, or am I experiencing burnout that is manifesting as a migraine?? Are they both the same thing?? Or are they just very linked? I have been doing vestibular rehabilitation therapy to help with my ability to use screens, and I think I will bring this up to my vestibular therapist to see if they have any knowledge about this. I know I just wrote a huge comment about myself here, I just really wanted to show how I have come to start thinking along the same lines as you. I would be extremely interested to see what your thoughts are on this so many months later. Did you ever get to talk to any of your doctors about it? Have you managed to recover?

I've had botox for migraines. In order to get them you need a referral to a neurologist and then they have to give you MRI to make sure theres nothing abnormal causing the migraines then you have to try at least two other medications and physical therapy to be approved for it. The shots themselves are painful as hell. They give you 31 shots across your forehead neck, and scalp. They are supposed to last at least 4 to 8 weeks but you cant get them again for 12 weeks. And when they wear off the migraines you get are ten times worse. If you are a daily migraine sufferer you might think 4 weeks without one is worth it but the one you get afterwards cant be cured by anything over the counter. Your eye feels like its falling out of your head and you may end up with muscle degeneration or what I call Picasso Face. My next treatment was cervical steroid nerve injections in my neck. That is the better treatment option I think. But if you can get a referral to neurologist or pain management clinic I'd ask about all your options. Good luck.

I take migraine medication, and a muscle relaxer. But there‚Äôs no extensive treatment for the disease itself. Excedrin Migraine always worked best for my migraine headaches. It contains acetaminophen, aspirin and caffeine. But don‚Äôt get in the habit of reaching for it every time you get a mild headache, just bad ones. Stay hydrated. I like drinking Gatorade personally. Also, I would give it a few weeks for your body to adjust. Headaches may just be a temporary symptom that eventually goes away for the most part - it went away for me and typically wasn‚Äôt an issue after my body adjusted to the medication. Try to avoid having an overly sedentary lifestyle. Go for walks. Lift some dumbbells a few times a week. Jog in place. Have some moments dedicated to getting the heart pumping a little bit each week to help with the narcolepsy and achieve a good lifestyle balance. Best of luck.

Years of trial and error here. PT every two weeks with stimulated micro needling and deep massage release , strength training and using the iron neck , + meds. Knowing when I can push physically and knowing when I need to back off entirely to avoid flair ups. Personally found that things that cause me inflammation cause my flair ups to be even worse so I have cut down my diet a lot and avoid alcohol. I still get flair ups and regular pain, but major flair ups not as often or severe and no longer have what I used to call ‚Äòsuicide pain‚Äô (used to have chronic explosive headaches paired with neck pain, which are under control with migraine medication now) I think a lot of it comes with personal trial and error. I‚Äôve seen soo many doctors over the last few years , tried every therapy imaginable and suggested in these forums; did injections, ablasion, diff kinds of meds , diff kinds of pt etc to finally figure out what worked best for me. To your question tho I‚Äôd say I haven‚Äôt overcome on but I have figure out how to live normally with it. One other thing I‚Äôll mention in my story in the possibility it helps someone else: at first I was reluctant to , but don‚Äôt be afraid to step outside the in networkness of your hospital system. ( if you can afford to pay out of pocket ofc) I went to multiple in network PTs that didn‚Äôt help with my progress. I then did my own research and found someone who specializes in these areas of chronic pain and she is absolutely amazing in how much she‚Äôs helped me. I do pay out of pocket to see her. But it has been incredibly worth it and I would honestly pay double for how much it has helped. You never know , there may be a perfect match for you locally that you‚Äôre not gonna find in a big hospital system if they operate independently. Just my experience anyways
